THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Johnny Mosley,
      Employee, Respondent,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				MeadWestvaco,
      Inc., Employer, and S.C. Chamber of Commerce Manufacturers, SIF, Insurers, Petitioners,
				of whom
      MeadWestvaco, Inc., Employer, is the
      Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Charleston County
J. C. Buddy Nicholson, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-073
Submitted January 2, 2008 â€“ Filed February
  4, 2008Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Kirsten Leslie Barr, of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellant.
				Waring S. Howe, of Charleston, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  In
  this workersâ€™ compensation action, MeadWestvaco appeals from an order of the
  circuit court affirming a finding of the Appellate Panel of the South Carolina
  Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission (the Commission) that Johnny Mosleyâ€™s hip
  injuries were work-related and rendered him totally disabled.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On December 1, 1998, Johnny Mosley
  suffered an injury while working for Westvaco, now MeadWestvaco.Â  On this date,
  Mosley felt a pulling sensation in his back and down his leg while removing
  railroad spikes.Â  Mosley subsequently claimed the injury was work-related, and
  the claim was litigated.Â Â Â   
The
  matter was tried before the single commissioner of the Workersâ€™ Compensation
  Commission in August of 2000.Â  In an order filed in December of 2000, the
  single commissioner found Mosleyâ€™s injury â€œwas the unexpected and unlooked for
  result of work activity,â€ and therefore was compensable.Â  The single
  commissioner ordered MeadWestvaco to pay temporary total disability benefits
  and causally related medical care.Â  In April of 2001, the Commission affirmed
  the single commissionerâ€™s findings and also adopted those findings by
  reference.Â  This order was not appealed further.Â   
On August 16, 2001, Mosley sought the opinion and care of an
  orthopedic surgeon to address his physical ailments.Â  Dr. Howard Brilliant, an
  orthopedic surgeon, ultimately diagnosed Mosley as having osteoarthritis in his
  hips.Â  On May 13, 2003, Mosley underwent hip replacement surgery for his left
  hip, performed by Dr. Brilliant.
On April 9, 2004 MeadWestvaco filed a form requesting a hearing to
  address several issues regarding its liability for Mosleyâ€™s medical treatment
  and disability.Â  On June 22, 2004, the single commissioner heard evidence
  regarding, among other matters, whether Mosley was permanently and totally
  disabled and whether his hip injuries were causally related to the December 1,
  1998 accident.Â  The single commissioner found: 1) Mosleyâ€™s hip injuries were
  causally related to the December 1, 1998 accident as established by credible
  expert medical testimony and 2) Mosley was permanently and totally disabled due
  to the combination of his back and hip injuries. Â The single commissioner
  ordered MeadWestvaco to pay all lifetime medical expenses related to these
  injuries and permanent and total disability benefits to Mosley.Â Â Â Â   
MeadWestvaco appealed the single commissionerâ€™s findings to the
  Commission.Â  The Commission affirmed the single commissionerâ€™s decision in full
  and adopted the single commissionerâ€™s findings by reference.Â  Thereafter,
  MeadWestvaco appealed to the circuit court, arguing there was not substantial
  evidence to support the Commissionâ€™s findings.Â  The circuit court affirmed the
  Commissionâ€™s decision, and this appeal followed.Â   
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The
  Administrative Procedures Act establishes our standard of review for decisions
  by the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission as the â€œsubstantial
  evidenceâ€ standard.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 135, 276 S.E.2d
  304, 306 (1981). Â An appellate court may reverse or modify the Commissionâ€™s
  decision if the appellantâ€™s substantial rights have been prejudiced because the
  decision is affected by an error of law or is clearly erroneous in view of the
  reliable, probative, and substantial evidence on the whole record.Â  Id. at 132-33, 276 S.E.2d at 305; see
    also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5)(d) & (e) (Supp. 2006).Â  â€œSubstantial
  evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence nor evidence viewed from one side,
  but such evidence, when the whole record is considered, as would allow
  reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the Full Commission reached.â€ Shealy
    v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 455, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000).Â  
 
The
  Commission is the ultimate fact finder and is not bound by the single
  commissionerâ€™s findings of fact.Â  Ross v. Am. Red Cross, 298 S.C.
  490, 492, 381 S.E.2d 728, 730 (1989).Â  The final determination of witness
  credibility and the weight to be given to the evidence is reserved to the
  Commission.Â  Id.Â  In an appeal from the Commission, this court may not
  substitute its judgment for that of the Commission as to the weight of the
  evidence on questions of fact.Â  Frame v. Resort Servs., Inc., 357 S.C.
  520, 527, 593 S.E.2d 491, 495 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Accordingly, our review is
  limited to deciding only whether the Commissionâ€™s decision is unsupported by
  substantial evidence or is controlled by some error of law.Â  Rodriguez v.
    Romero, 363 S.C. 80, 84, 610 S.E.2d 488, 490 (2005).  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Mosleyâ€™s Hip Injuries
Initially, Mosley
  suggests the unappealed order of April 14, 2001 requires MeadWestvaco to pay
  for Mosleyâ€™s hip injuries.Â  We disagree, although we do recognize that
  MeadWestvaco has attempted in this action to relitigate the compensability of
  the underlying 1998 work related accident.  
The
  April 2001 order determined that Mosley â€œsuffered a compensable injury by
  accident arising out of and in the course of his employment on or around
  December 1, 1998.â€Â  The Commission found Mosley was â€œentitled to medical care
  for his back and lower extremitiesâ€ and ordered MeadWestvaco to provide
  â€œcausally related medical treatment/care.â€Â  MeadWestvaco did not appeal the
  decision further; therefore, it is the law
  of the case and has been decided with absolute finality.Â  See Charleston Lumber Co. v. Miller Housing Corp., 338 S.C. 171,
  175, 525 S.E.2d 869, 871 (2000) (stating an unchallenged or unappealed ruling
  is the law of the case).
The
  full nature and extent of Mosleyâ€™s injuries, however, had not fully been
  discovered at the time of the Commissionâ€™s April 14, 2001 decision.Â Â  The
  evidence presented to the Commission showed that Mosley suffered from back and
  leg pain.Â Â  Mosleyâ€™s doctors did not diagnose the osteoarthritis in his hips
  until August 2001.Â  The issue of whether these specific hip injuries were
  causally related to the December 1, 1998 accident was not before the
  Commission.Â  Therefore, although the Commissionâ€™s finding that Mosley suffered
  a compensable injury from the December 1, 1998 accident is the law of the case,
  the issue of whether Mosleyâ€™s hip injuries were causally related has not been determined
  with finality.Â  Accordingly, MeadWestvaco properly brought the matter before
  the Commission for determination, and we now turn to MeadWestvacoâ€™s arguments
  on appeal.
MeadWestvaco
  first argues Mosley did not present substantial evidence to support a finding
  that Mosleyâ€™s accident subsequently caused his hip injuries.Â  We disagree.Â  
 
Specifically,
  MeadWestvaco argues that the Commission erred in relying on the testimony of
  Dr. Brilliant, who testified Mosleyâ€™s hip injuries were causally related to the
  December 1, 1998 accident.Â  In making this argument, MeadWestvaco asserts Dr.
  Brilliantâ€™s expert opinion was based on nonexistent facts and therefore the
  probative value of his testimony â€œis destroyed.â€Â Â Â   
As
  MeadWestvaco correctly points out, â€œit is well settled that the probative value
  of expert testimony, based upon hypothetical facts, stands or falls on the
  existence or nonexistence of the facts upon which it is predicated.â€Â  Chapman
    v. Foremost Dairies, Inc.,  249 S.C. 438, 449, 154 S.E.2d 845,
  851 (1967).Â  The key issue for determining whether such testimony is
  probative, then, is whether the hypothetical facts relied upon by the expert
  witness are supported by evidence.Â  See id.Â  If the hypothetical
  facts are supported by evidence within the record, the probative value of the
  expertâ€™s testimony is not destroyed.Â  Id.Â Â   
At
  his deposition, Dr. Brilliant testified made several assumptions in order to
  have an opinion to a reasonable degree of medical certainty as to how
  osteoarthritis developed in Mosleyâ€™s hips.Â  He explained:

	The assumptions are that Mr. Mosley was indeed hurt at
  work in December and that since that time until I saw him over the three-year
  period that he had back and left leg pain.Â  That the pain wasnâ€™t --did not
  respond to the injections for his back.Â  Then I -- I feel pretty strongly that
  he got hurt at work.Â  

In
  arguing Dr. Brilliant based his testimony upon nonexistent facts, MeadWestvaco
  focuses on Dr. Brilliantâ€™s assumption that Mosleyâ€™s pain did not respond to the
  injections, pointing to multiple notations within Mosleyâ€™s medical records
  indicating that his pain improved following the epidural steroid injections. 
 
While
  the notations in the medical records suggest the epidural steroid injections
  had some effect, there is evidence in the record which supports a conclusion
  that Mosleyâ€™s pain did not respond to the injections because they did not
  provide an ultimate solution to Mosleyâ€™s problem.Â  Indeed, Dr. Brilliant
  testified that he believed the December 1, 1998 accident caused Mosleyâ€™s hip
  condition because â€œhe was working until he got hurt on that day and from that
  day on he continued to have problems.â€Â  Dr. Richardson, the physician who
  treated Mosley for his back injuries and administered the majority of the
  injections, testified these injections only temporarily reduced Mosleyâ€™s pain
  so that he would need periodic injections â€œfor the foreseeable future.â€Â  Dr.
  Richardson also testified that aside from these injections, there was nothing
  else that he could do for Mosleyâ€™s pain.Â   
Because
  there is evidence that supports Dr. Brilliantâ€™s assumption that Mosleyâ€™s back
  and leg pain did not respond to these injections, the probative value of his
  testimony is not â€œdestroyed,â€ as MeadWestvaco argues.Â  The existence of
  evidence supporting a conclusion contrary to the Commissionâ€™s findings does not
  mean the Commissionâ€™s determination is unsupported by substantial evidence.Â  Ellis
    v. Spartan Mills, 276 S.C. 216, 218, 277 S.E.2d 590, 591 (1981).Â  The
  credibility and weight of the doctorâ€™s testimony was, of course, for the
  Commission as the trier of facts.Â  See Chapman, 249 S.C. at 449,
  154 S.E.2d at 851 (citing McCarty v. Kendall Co., 238 S.C. 493, 120
  S.E.2d 860 (1961)).Â  Therefore, the Commission did not err in relying on Dr.
  Brilliantâ€™s testimony that Mosleyâ€™s hip injuries were causally related to the
  December 1, 1998 accident.  
II.Â  Permanent and Total Disability.
MeadWestvaco
  also argues the Commission erred in finding Mosley was permanently and totally
  disabled.Â  We disagree.Â   
A
  claimant may establish total disability in one of three ways under S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 42-9-10 (Supp. 2006).Â  See Wigfall v. Tideland Utils., Inc.,
  354 S.C. 100, 105, 580 S.E.2d 100, 102 (2003).  First, a claimant may be
  presumptively totally disabled by showing a physical injury enumerated in section
  42-9-10. Id.  If the claimantâ€™s injury is one of the enumerated
  injuries, â€œthe claimant need not show a loss of earning capacity.â€  Id.  Loss of earning capacity is conclusively presumed in such a situation
  â€œbecause the Legislature has categorized certain types of injuries as per se totally disabling . . . .â€  Id.  Second, a claimant
  may establish total disability under section 42-9-10 by showing an injury
  diminished earning capacity to such an extent as to entitle the claimant to
  total disability.Â  Id.  It follows that in this scenario, a
  claimant bears the burden of proving lost earning capacity to establish total
  disability.Â  Third, a claimant may establish total disability through multiple
  physical injuries.  Id. at 106, 580 S.E.2d at 103.  Under this
  scenario a claimant who has a scheduled injury under section 42-9-30 must show
  an additional injury.  Id. Â Â   
A.Â Â Combination of Injuries
MeadWestvaco
  first argues that Mosley suffered only a single scheduled injury under S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-30 (1985 & Supp. 2006) and is therefore not entitled to
  benefits under section 42-9-10.Â  We disagree.
As
  discussed in the preceding section, there was substantial evidence to support
  the Commissionâ€™s finding that Mosleyâ€™s hip injuries were causally related to
  the December 1, 1998 accident.Â  In addition to these injuries, Mosleyâ€™s back
  injuries have been established through the prior Commission decision of April 14,
  2001.Â  Accordingly, Mosleyâ€™s situation falls under the third category for
  recovery pursuant to section 42-9-10, i.e., establishing total disability
  through multiple physical injuries.Â  Indeed, the single commissioner found
  Mosley is permanently and totally disabled â€œbecause of the combination of
  injuries to the back and hipsâ€ under section 42-9-10. Â Because there is
  evidence in the record to support the conclusion Mosleyâ€™s hip injuries were
  causally related to the December 1, 1998 accident, the Commissionâ€™s finding
  that Mosley was entitled to recover under section 42-9-10 due to multiple
  injuries is also supported by substantial evidence.Â  Therefore, we may not
  disturb this finding on appeal.Â   
B.Â Â Reasonable
  Efforts to Secure Employment
MeadWestvacoâ€™s
  next argument is that Mosley failed to meet his burden of proving total
  disability because he did not make reasonable efforts to secure employment.Â  We
  note the issue of whether Mosley met his burden under the Act is not preserved
  for our review.Â  In order to be preserved for our review, an issue must be
  raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.Â  In re Michael H., 360 S.C.
  540, 546, 602 S.E.2d 729, 732 (2004) (â€œAn issue may not be raised for the first
  time on appeal.Â  In order to preserve an issue for appeal, it must be raised to
  and ruled upon by the trial court.â€); Lucas v. Rawl Family Ltd. Pâ€™ship,
  359 S.C. 505, 510-11, 598 S.E.2d 712, 715 (2004) (â€œIt is well settled that, but
  for a very few exceptional circumstances, an appellate court cannot address an
  issue unless it was raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.â€).Â  Based on
  the trial record, we find MeadWestvaco failed to raise this issue to either the
  Commission or the circuit court for review, and consequently the issue was
  never ruled upon.Â  This issue is not preserved for our review.Â   
CONCLUSION
The judgment of the
  circuit court is  
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and
  KITTREDGE and THOMAS, JJ., concur.

title: Klein v. Klein
text:
THIS
  OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
  PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


	
		
			
				Mark T. Klein, Appellant,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Sherry G.
      Klein, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Pickens County
Â Tommy B. Edwards, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-074
Submitted January 2, 2008 â€“ Filed February
  4, 2008

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Robert Scott Dover, of Pickens, for Appellant.Â  
				
				Woodrow Grady Jordan, of Easley, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  In
  this appeal arising from a Rule to Show Cause action,Â  Mark T. Klein (Husband)
  argues the family court erred in awarding Sherry G. Klein (Wife) affirmative
  relief and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We affirm.Â Â   
FACTS
Husband
  and Wife were married on June 16, 1972.Â  The parties had one son, Mark T.
  Klein, II, born on August 8, 1975.Â  During the marriage, Husband owned seven
  pieces of real estate encumbered by a single mortgage (the mortgage) with
  Oconee Savings and Loan Association.Â   
The
  parties separated in November 1988, and shortly thereafter, Husband filed for
  divorce.Â  The parties subsequently reached a separation agreement resolving all
  issues regarding the divorce. Â Â 
The separation
  agreement specifically addressed the disposition of three pieces of Husbandâ€™s
  real property.Â  Under the agreement, Husband agreed to be responsible for the
  mortgage covering the various properties.Â  Husband also agreed to transfer fee
  simple title of the marital home (Lot 8) to Wife when the partiesâ€™ son reached
  the age of eighteen.Â  Wife agreed to waive any right to Husbandâ€™s four-plex
  house (Lot 6).Â  Lastly, Husband agreed to give Wife one-half of â€œthe net
  proceeds after costs of saleâ€ when the remaining property (Lot 9) was sold.Â  
 
On May 22, 1989,
  the parties appeared before the family court, seeking the courtâ€™s approval of
  the partiesâ€™ separation agreement and requesting a ruling regarding separate
  maintenance and support.Â  The family court incorporated the agreement into its
  order after concluding it was fair and reasonable and awarded Wife separate
  maintenance and support pending the final order.Â  On January 12, 1990, the
  family court issued a final decree of divorce.
On January 4, 1990,
  Husband sold Lot 6 and Lot 9 for $198,000.Â  Husbandâ€™s records indicate the sale
  price of Lot 9 was $73,000, while the price for Lot 6 was $125,000.Â  Prior to
  this sale, Husband had sold other lots encumbered by the mortgage, and the net
  proceeds from these prior sales were applied to the satisfaction of the
  mortgage.Â  At the time of the January sale, the remaining balance on the
  mortgage was $137,702.91.Â  Husbandâ€™s records indicated net proceeds of
  $45,374.55 after paying the balance on the mortgage, real estate commission,
  and taxes on the properties.Â  On January 5, 1990, Husbandâ€™s attorney forwarded
  a check in the amount of $45,374.55 to the trust account of Acker, Acker, Floyd
  & Welmaker to be escrowed pending the distribution of the proceeds between
  Husband and Wife.Â Â   
On April 7, 2004,
  Wife filed a Rule to Show Cause against Husband, requesting the family court
  find Husband in contempt.Â  Specifically, Wife alleged Husband failed to convey
  fee simple title to Lot 8 in full because he conveyed a one-half interest in
  the property to her and a one-half interest to the partiesâ€™ son.Â  Wife also
  alleged Husband was in contempt because he failed to pay her one-half of the
  net proceeds from the sale of Lot 9.Â  Lastly, Wife sought attorneyâ€™s fees for
  the Rule to Show Cause action.Â Â   
Following Husbandâ€™s
  receipt of notice for the Rule to Show Cause, the partiesâ€™ son executed a deed
  conveying his one-half interest in Lot 8 to Wife.Â  Husband also paid Wifeâ€™s
  attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â   
However,
  at the Rule to Show Cause hearing on April 17, 2006, Husband denied that Wife
  was entitled to any of the net proceeds he received from the sale of the two
  lots.Â  Husband argued he applied the entirety of the sales price from the sale
  of Lot 9 to satisfy the mortgage, leaving no proceeds for Wife from the sale.Â 
  Husband also claimed the $45,374.55 in proceeds were entirely from the sale of Lot 6.Â  
 
In
  its Rule to Show Cause Order, dated May 8, 2006, the family court held a
  finding of contempt in abeyance because (1) Wife waited a long time to bring
  the action and (2) the determination of the amount due under the final order
  was confusing, such that the parties did not have a clear method for computing
  the net proceeds.Â  The court adopted Wifeâ€™s rationale for distributing the
  $45,374.55 based on Lot 9â€™s ratable share of the sales price and ordered
  Husband to pay Wife $8,229.Â  Additionally, the family court ordered Husband to
  pay Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees in the amount of $573.Â  Husband appeals.Â Â Â   
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In
  appeals from the family court, this Court may find facts in accordance with its
  own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Nasser-Moghaddassi v.
    Moghaddassi, 364 S.C. 182, 189, 612 S.E.2d 707, 711 (Ct. App.
  2005).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require this Court to
  disregard the family courtâ€™s findings.Â  Lacke v. Lacke, 362 S.C. 302,
  307, 608 S.E.2d 147, 149-50 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Nor must we ignore the fact that
  the family court judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better
  position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their
  testimony.Â  Scott v. Scott, 354 S.C. 118, 124, 579 S.E.2d 620, 623
  (2003).Â  However, our broad scope of review does not relieve the appellant of
  the burden of convincing this Court that the family court committed error.Â  Nasser-Moghaddassi,
  364 S.C. at 190, 612 S.E.2d at 711.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Admissibility of Evidence
Husband
  argues the family court erred in admitting a document illustrating Wifeâ€™s
  calculations of the â€œnet proceedsâ€ owed to her under the real estate sale
  because Wife laid no foundation for its admissibility.Â  We disagree.  
The
  admission or exclusion of evidence at trial is within the sound discretion of
  the court.Â  Grand Strand Constr. Co., Inc. v. Graves, 269 S.C. 594, 595,
  239 S.E.2d 81, 81 (1977).Â  On appeal, the exercise of the trial courtâ€™s
  discretion will not be disturbed unless there is a showing of (1) a clear abuse
  of discretion, (2) the commission of legal error in the exercise of discretion,
  and (3) prejudice to the rights of the appellant.Â  Rutledge v. St. Paul Fire
    & Marine Ins. Co., 286 S.C. 360, 366, 334 S.E.2d 131, 135 (Ct.
  App. 1985).  
At
  trial, Husband objected to the admission of Wifeâ€™s document, arguing Wife was
  not aware of its contents.Â  Following the objection, Wife testified the
  document contained her calculations of the amount owed to her based on the
  sales prices of the two properties.Â  The family court overruled Husbandâ€™s
  objection and admitted the document.Â   
Rule
  901(a) of the South Carolina Rules of Evidence states: â€œThe requirement of
  authentication or identification as a condition precedent to admissibility is
  satisfied by evidence sufficient to support a finding that the matter in
  question is what its proponent claims.â€Â  Testimony of a witness
  with knowledge that â€œa matter is what it is claimed to beâ€ is a method of
  authentication conforming to the requirements of Rule 901.Â  Rule 901(b)(1),Â 
  SCRE.
Wife
  offered the document to demonstrate her calculation of the figure she claimed she
  was owed from the sale of Lot 9.Â  She expressly testified the document
  represented this calculation and the figure she ultimately claimed to be owed. Â Thus,
  Wifeâ€™s testimony provided a proper authentication for the admission of the
  document into evidence.
Furthermore,
  the figures contained in the document had already been properly admitted into
  evidence.Â  The document included the figures from the sale of Lot 9 as
  contained in two previous exhibits, which were already stipulated into evidence
  by the parties.Â  The document also included the figure Wife testified she
  believed to be her share from the sale of Lot 9.Â  In this regard, the document
  is demonstrative evidence offered as an aid to the fact finder.Â  Demonstrative
  evidence explains or summarizes other evidence and testimony.Â  Clark v. Cantrell, 339 S.C. 369, 383, 529 S.E.2d 528, 535 (2000).Â  Such
  evidence â€œmust rely on other material testimony for relevance.â€Â  Id.Â  Wifeâ€™s document simply illustrates how, from the figures in the two prior
  exhibits, Wife calculated the amount she claimed to be owed.Â  It is of no
  consequence that she did not testify to having first-hand knowledge of the
  figures contained in the two previous exhibits as they were already admitted
  into evidence.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â   
Additionally, the
  admission of improper evidence is harmless when it is merely cumulative to
  other evidence.Â  Muir v. C.R. Bard, Inc., 336 S.C. 266, 300, 519 S.E.2d
  583, 600 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Even if we agreed with Husbandâ€™s argument, we must
  not disturb the family courtâ€™s decision to admit Wifeâ€™s document because
  Husband has made no showing that he has suffered prejudice.Â  As noted
  previously, the document contained figures from evidence which had already been
  properly admitted.Â  Therefore, Husband has not suffered prejudice, and the
  family courtâ€™s decision to admit Wifeâ€™s document was not reversible error.Â  
 
II. Reopening of Wifeâ€™s Case at
  Trial
Husband argues the family court erred in allowing Wife to reopen
  her case.Â  We disagree.Â   
The decision to reopen the evidence is within the sound discretion
  of the trial court and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of that
  discretion.Â  Brown v. La France Indus., a Div. of Riegel Textile Corp., 
  286 S.C. 319, 324-25, 333 S.E.2d 348, 351 (Ct. App. 1985). In South Carolina, it is well established that the decision of the trial court to allow a
  party to reopen his case will not be reversed unless it results in prejudice to
  the opposing party.Â  Id.Â Â  The wide latitude afforded
  to the trial court permits the court to reopen the case and allow the
  introduction of additional evidence even after a motion for a nonsuit is made.Â  Rakestraw v. Allstate Ins. Co., 238 S.C. 217, 222, 119 S.E.2d 746,
  748 (1961) (citations omitted).Â   
We note it is unclear from the record whether Wife had rested her
  case as Husband claims.Â  After Husbandâ€™s attorney cross-examined Wife, the
  family court instructed Wife to step down and asked if Wifeâ€™s attorney had â€œ[a]nything
  else,â€ to which Wifeâ€™s attorney responded, â€œNo, sir.â€Â  The court then asked Husbandâ€™s
  attorney whether he had any additional testimony, and Husbandâ€™s attorney
  stated, â€œIf [Wife] rests, I have a motion.â€Â  Wifeâ€™s attorney in kind responded,
  â€œIâ€™ll call [Husband].â€Â  It is plausible that Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s response of â€œNo,
  sirâ€ to the family courtâ€™s initial question meant Wifeâ€™s attorney had no
  additional questions for Wife and that only after calling Husband to the stand
  would Wife rest her case.Â   
Regardless, under this Stateâ€™s case law, the family court could
  have subsequently allowed additional evidence even if the Wife had rested her
  case and Husband had made his directed verdict motion.Â  See id.Â  Further,
  Husband does not argue he suffered prejudice by the family courtâ€™s decision.Â 
  Absent a showing of prejudice, we cannot disturb the decision of the family
  court.Â Â  Brown, 286 S.C. at 324-25, 333 S.E.2d at 351. 
III. Affirmative Relief
Husband
  argues the family court erred in awarding Wife affirmative relief.Â  We
  disagree.Â   
A. Contempt
Husband
  contends because the family court did not find him in contempt, it erred in
  awarding Wife affirmative relief.Â  We disagree.Â   
â€œIt
  is well settled that contempt results from willful disobedience of a court
  order; and before a person may be held in contempt, the record must be clear
  and specific as to acts or conduct upon which the contempt is based.â€ Cheap-Oâ€™s
    Truck Stop, Inc., 350 S.C. 596, 612, 567 S.E.2d 514, 522 (Ct. App. 2002)
  (quoting State v. Bevilacqua,
  316 S.C. 122, 129, 447 S.E.2d 213, 217 (Ct. App. 1994)). A willful act is â€œone
  done voluntarily and intentionally with the specific intent to do something the
  law forbids, or with the specific intent to fail to do something the law
  requires to be done; that is to say with bad purpose either to disobey or
  disregard the law.â€Â  Id. (citations omitted).
The
  family court held the issue of contempt in abeyance in part because Wife waited
  an extended period of time to bring the Rule to Show Cause action.Â  We agree
  with the family court when it also stated, â€œ[T]he determination in the amount due
  was confusing and the prior [o]rder did not help the parties in providing a
  clear cut methodology from which the amount was to be derive[d].â€Â  Because the
  prior final order did not specify what constituted net proceeds and how those
  proceeds were to be deduced, the family court felt it was unclear as to whether
  Husband willfully disobeyed the final order.Â  However, based on our own view of
  the preponderance of the evidence, we find the ambiguity in the final order
  prevents a finding of contempt against Husband.Â  The facts and circumstances of
  this case do not support a finding of contempt.Â  See Smith v. Smith,
  359 S.C. 393, 397, 597, S.E.2d 188, 189 (Ct. App. 2004) (finding provision in
  settlement agreement was ambiguous such that family court was proper to not
  hold the husband in contempt).Â   
Despite
  this, we agree with the family court when it stated, â€œ[A] common sense and
  reasonable interpretation of [the] order was to give some value out of the sale
  of Lot 9 to [Wife].â€Â  As stated in further detail below, because of the
  ambiguity in the final order, it was proper to award affirmative relief to
  Wife, despite the family courtâ€™s failure to find Husband in contempt.Â 
  Therefore, Husbandâ€™s argument is without merit.Â   
B. Interpretation of the Final
  Order and Separation Agreement
Husband
  also contends the family court erred in its interpretation of the prior final
  order and in granting Wife $8,229 in affirmative relief because it failed to
  find an ambiguity in the prior order.Â  Specifically, Husband contends the
  family court erred by inserting essential terms into the partiesâ€™ agreement and
  prorating the mortgage between Lot 6 and Lot 9.Â  We disagree.
In South Carolina, the construction of a separation agreement is a matter of contract law.Â  Estate
  of Revis by Revis v. Revis, 326 S.C. 470, 477, 484 S.E.2d 112, 116 (Ct.
  App. 1997).Â  â€œIn the enforcement of an agreement, the court does not have the
  authority to modify terms that are clear and unambiguous on their face.â€Â  Messer
    v. Messer, 359 S.C. 614, 621, 598 S.E.2d 310, 314 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œWhere
  an agreement is clear and capable of legal construction the courtâ€™s only
  function is to interpret its lawful meaning and the intention of the parties as
  found within the agreement and give effect to them.â€Â  Bogan v. Bogan,
  298 S.C. 139, 142, 378 S.E.2d 606, 608 (Ct. App. 1989).Â  â€œTo discover the
  intention of a contract, the court must first look to its language - if the
  language is perfectly plain and capable of legal construction, it alone
  determines the documentâ€™s force and effect.â€Â  Davis v. Davis, 
  372 S.C. 64, 75, 641 S.E.2d 446, 452 (Ct. App. 2006).Â Â   
On
  the other hand, â€œ[a]n ambiguous contract is one capable of being understood in
  more ways than one, an agreement obscure in meaning through indefiniteness of
  expression, or having a double meaning.â€Â  Estate of Revis, 326 S.C. at
  479, 484 S.E.2d at 117.Â  Whether or not an ambiguity exists in an agreement
  must be determined from the language of the instrument. Â Steffenson
    v. Olsen, 360 S.C. 318, 322, 600 S.E.2d 129, 131 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  When an
  agreement is susceptible of more than one interpretation, it is ambiguous and
  the court should seek to determine the intent of the parties.Â  Estate of
    Revis, 326 S.C. at 477-78, 484 S.E.2d at 117.Â  â€œ[W]here an agreement has
  been merged into a courts [sic] decree, the decree, to the extent possible,
  should be construed to effect the intent of both the judge and the parties.â€Â  Messer,
  359 S.C. at 628, 598 S.E.2d at 318.Â  Additionally, â€œ[a] court approved divorce
  settlement must be viewed in accordance with principles of equity and there is
  implied in every such agreement a requirement of reasonableness.â€Â  Ebert v.
    Ebert, 320 S.C. 331, 340, 465 S.E.2d 121, 126 (Ct. App. 1995) (quoting 17A
  Am. Jur. 2d Contracts Â§ 479 (1991)).
We
  agree with the family courtâ€™s finding that the final order was ambiguous.Â  The
  language of the separation agreement, adopted in the final order and divorce
  decree, is as follows: â€œThe [Husband]
  agrees to be responsible for the outstanding mortgage covering the various properties
  which has an approximate balance at this time of $135,000.00. . . .
  Additionally, the [Husband] will give [Wife] one-half (50%) of the net proceeds
  after costs of sale of the remaining duplex house on Lot 9, Willowood Sub.â€Â  
 
We
  agree with the family court that, looking at the language of the final order,
  it is not clear how the satisfaction of the mortgage is to be apportioned among
  the remaining properties, leaving the order susceptible to more than one
  interpretation.Â  We find the family court was not unreasonable in its
  assessment of the partiesâ€™ intent, in that â€œa common sense and reasonable
  interpretation of [the] [o]rder was to give some value out of the sale of Lot 9 to [Wife].â€Â  For these reasons, we hold that the family court did not err in
  interpreting the final order.  
We
  also hold the family courtâ€™s grant of affirmative relief was reasonable
  considering the language of the order.Â  The separation agreement, as
  incorporated into the final order, is susceptible to multiple interpretations,
  which may have allowed Wife to claim a greater share of the proceeds from the
  sale of Lot 9.Â  For example, the family court found the intent behind the final
  order was to divide the proceeds â€œafter taking into account payoff of the
  mortgage.â€Â  The language of the final order, however, might suggest that the
  mortgage is not to be considered at all since Husband agreed â€œto be responsible
  for the payment of the outstanding mortgage.â€Â  Nevertheless, Wife only sought
  relief based on a ratable share of the total sale prices of Lot 9 and Lot 6.Â  See Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d
  543, 546 (2000) (holding issues not raised to or ruled upon by the trial court
  may not be considered on appeal).Â  In this regard, the family courtâ€™s adoption
  of Wifeâ€™s rationale was reasonable in light of the language of the agreement,
  and therefore, the family court did not err in granting the relief
  requested.Â Â Â   
IV. Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Husband
  argues the family court erred in awarding Wife attorneyâ€™s fees because the
  court did not find him in contempt, and therefore, the court had no basis for
  awarding attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We disagree.
When
  a party in an action seeks attorneyâ€™s fees, the family court has the statutory
  authority to award â€œa reasonable sum for the claim if
  it appears well-founded.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(A)(38)
  (Supp.2006).Â  An attorneyâ€™s fees award is within the sound discretion of the
  family court and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of
  discretion.Â  Davis, 372 S.C. at 88, 641 S.E.2d at 458.
Our
  review of the record reveals no abuse of discretion.Â  Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees
  were incurred as a result of a contempt proceeding involving Husband.Â  Wife
  initiated the action in a good faith belief that Husband was willfully disobeying
  a prior order of the family court.Â  While we find Husband was not technically
  in contempt, Wife incurred attorneyâ€™s fees and costs in an effort to enforce
  compliance with a previous court order.Â  See Christy v. Christy,
  317 S.C. 145, 150-51, 452 S.E.2d 1, 4 (Ct. App. 1994) (holding award of
  attorneyâ€™s fees against a husband was proper even though the family court
  failed to find the husband in contempt because the fees were incurred as a
  result of the contempt proceeding and the matter was initiated by the wife to
  force compliance with the courtâ€™s order).Â  Therefore, Wifeâ€™s claim for
  attorneyâ€™s fees is well founded, and we find no abuse of discretion in the
  family courtâ€™s award of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â   
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the order of the family
  court is  
AFFIRMED.[1]Â   
ANDERSON, SHORT,
  and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Wal-Mart
      Stores, Inc., Employer, and American Homes Assurance, Carrier, Appellants,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				William
      Waxenfelter, Employee, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Horry County
Â John L. Breeden, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008- UP-075
Submitted January 1, 2008 â€“ Filed February
  4, 2008

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Johnnie W. Baxley, III, Mount Pleasant, for Appellants.
				John S. Nichols, Bluestein, of Columbia, and Kenneth W. Harrell,
  of North Charleston, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â 
  William Waxenfelter (Waxenfelter) sustained a compensable injury to his spine, legs,
  and right hip while employed at Wal-Mart.Â  Subsequently, Waxenfelter asserted a
  change of condition for the worse pursuant to South Carolina Code section
  42-17-90 (Supp. 2006) and was awarded temporary total disability benefits.Â 
  Wal-Mart and American Homes Assurance (collectively Wal-Mart) appeal this
  award, claiming Waxenfelterâ€™s back infection severed the causal connection
  between his initial compensable injury and resulting worsening of condition.Â 
  We affirm.
FACTS
In April 2003, Waxenfelter was employed at Wal-Mart
  as the sporting goods manager.Â  He was injured when he bent over to move a
  dividing bar that separated a display of folding chairs, which caused a severe
  pain in his lower back and resulted in a compensable injury to his spine, legs,
  and right hip. Â His claim was settled pursuant to a Form 16 settlement
  agreement.Â  In July 2004, Waxenfelter filed a Form 50, asserting a change of
  condition for the worse and requesting temporary total disability benefits and
  additional medical treatment.Â  Wal-Mart denied that Waxenfelter had sustained a
  compensable worsening of his condition.Â    
At
  the Form 50 hearing, Wal-Mart did not present any witnesses.Â  Waxenfelter
  testified on his own behalf.Â  Both sides submitted numerous medical reports,
  including those of orthopedists, Dr. Bauerle and Dr. Wilkins, and Waxenfelter
  also submitted the deposition testimony of orthopedist Dr. Poletti.Â   
 
Waxenfelter
  testified that he incurred two previous lower back injuries while employed at
  Wal-Mart, but he was able to return to work without restriction.Â  After the
  April 2003 injury, Waxenfelter was out of work for approximately five weeks but
  returned to full-time employment with weight-lifting restrictions.Â  While his
  back pain in late 2003 was â€œlow level and manageable,â€ by May 2004, his pain
  was â€œexcruciating.â€Â  In early May 2004, Waxenfelter stated he began to
  experience severe spasms in his back.Â  These spasms were â€œso hard that [he]
  went out of bed onto the floor, literally, in one motion.â€Â  From that time
  until the surgery, he testified he experienced the most â€œhorrendous painâ€ he
  had â€œever known in his life,â€ such that â€œif the scale is one to ten [the pain]
  was off the scale.â€Â   
Dr.
  Bauerle examined Waxenfelter in April 2003 after his initial injury and noted
  Waxenfelter sustained a â€œWorkerâ€™s Compensation injury with thoracolumbar
  scoliosis and multilevel degenerative disc disease.â€Â  Dr. Bauerle then referred
  Waxenfelter to Dr. Wilkins for non-surgical rehabilitation. Â Dr. Wilkins examined
  Waxenfelter in April 2003 and again in May 2004 when Waxenfelter complained of
  increased lower back pain. Â Based on an MRI scan in May 2004, Dr.
  Wilkins opined that Waxenfelter suffered from a â€œlarge herniationâ€ to his L1-L2
  disc â€œrelated to his previous workmanâ€™s compensation injury.â€Â  Waxenfelter was
  subsequently hospitalized for four days in May 2004 as a result of his severe
  back pain.Â Â   
In
  June 2004, Dr. Bauerle and Dr. Poletti treated Waxenfelter for an exacerbation
  of his symptoms, but in July 2004, Waxenfelter had to undergo emergency surgery
  due to a large infection at his L1-L2 disc, which caused a complete collapse of
  the disc space. Â Prior to performing the emergency surgery, Dr. Poletti noted
  Waxenfelterâ€™s MRI indicated â€œa very significant disc herniation at L1-L2 which
  is [a] new onset compared to the previous [injury].â€Â  He further stated,
  â€œ[Waxenfelter] is even worsening subjectively.â€ Â One month later, Dr. Poletti
  stated, â€œMr. Waxenfelter is going to be totally disabled.Â  He is not going to
  be capable of returning to work in the future.â€Â Â   
Dr.
  Poletti stated in his deposition, â€œ[Waxenfelterâ€™s disc] was originally
  herniated back in . . . 2003.Â  It had probably been herniated for a long time
  and then got worse.â€ Â While Dr. Poletti noted he removed an epidural abscess in
  July 2004, he also stated, â€œI canâ€™t say for certain that this was an epidural
  abscess the whole time.Â  And it theoretically could have been a disc herniation
  that became superinfected with an abscess.â€Â  In attempting to pinpoint the
  origin of the back infection, which precipitated the surgery, Dr. Poletti
  alternatively opined, â€œ[T]he whole scenario is just as plausible that he
  ruptured this disc and, in the process of getting treated with it, infection
  was seeded and it developed into an abscess.â€
When
  questioned about whether Waxenfelterâ€™s spine condition had worsened since Dr.
  Poletti first examined Waxenfelter in 2003, Dr. Poletti responded, â€œYes. No
  question.â€ Â However, Dr. Poletti felt that he could not say with a
  reasonable degree of medical certainty whether a causal relationship existed
  between the infection causing the July 2004 surgery and the pre-existing work
  injuries.Â  Since that time, Waxenfelter has undergone pain management treatment
  and epidural steroid injections.Â   
Based
  on this evidence, the Single Commissioner found Waxenfelter sustained a
  compensable change of condition for the worse and awarded him additional
  medical treatment and temporary total disability benefits from May 8, 2004, the
  last day he was able to work, until the benefits could be properly terminated.[1]Â 
  Wal-Mart appealed, and the Appellate Panel affirmed the Single Commissioner.Â 
  Wal-Mart appealed to the circuit court, which affirmed the Appellate Panel.Â 
  Wal-Mart now appeals to this Court.
STANDARD
  OF REVIEW
The
  Administrative Procedures Act applies to appeals from decisions of the Workersâ€™
  Compensation Commission (the Commission).Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C.
  130, 134-35, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  In an appeal from the Commission,
  neither this Court nor the circuit court may substitute its judgment for that
  of the Commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact, but it
  may reverse when the decision is affected by an error of law.Â  Corbin v.
    Kohler Co., 351 S.C. 613, 617, 571 S.E.2d 92, 95 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  
 
â€œAny
  review of the [C]ommissionâ€™s factual findings is governed by the substantial
  evidence standard.â€Â  Lockridge v. Santens of Am., Inc., 344 S.C. 511,
  515, 544 S.E.2d 842, 844 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œSubstantial evidenceâ€ is not a mere
  scintilla of evidence nor evidence viewed blindly from one side of the case,
  but is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow
  reasonable minds to reach the conclusion that the Commission reached or must
  have reached in order to justify its action. Â Palmetto Alliance, Inc. v.
    S.C. Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 282 S.C. 430, 432, 319 S.E.2d 695, 696 (1984). Â 
â€œThe
  possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not
  prevent an administrative agencyâ€™s finding from being supported by substantial
  evidence.â€Â  Lee v. Harborside CafÃ©, 350 S.C. 74, 78, 564 S.E.2d 354, 356
  (Ct. App. 2002) (internal quotations and citations omitted).Â  Accordingly, we
  limit review to deciding whether the Commissionâ€™s decision is unsupported by
  substantial evidence or is controlled by some error of law.Â  Corbin, 351
  S.C. at 617, 571 S.E.2d at 95.  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Wal-Mart contends Waxenfelterâ€™s spinal infection severed the causal connection between his
  initial compensable injury and his resulting worsening of condition.Â  We
  disagree.
Generally, an
  appeal of a workersâ€™ compensation order is concerned with the conditions prior
  to and at the time of the original award of the Commission. Â Causby v. Rock Hill Printing & Finishing Co., 249 S.C. 225, 228, 153 S.E.2d 697, 698-99
  (1967).Â  Review for a change of condition is concerned with conditions that
  have arisen after the compensable injury. Â Id.Â  When an employee shows a
  change of condition, â€œ[T]he Commission may review an award and on that review
  may make an award ending, diminishing, or increasing the compensation
  previously awarded . . . .â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-17-90 (Supp. 2006).  
A change
  of condition occurs when the employee experiences a change of physical condition
  as a result of his original injury, occurring after the first award. Â Causby,
  249 S.C. at 227, 153 S.E.2d at 698. Â To justify a modification of an award
  based on a change of condition, the employee must show the change of condition
  and its causal connection to the original compensable accident. Â Krell v. S.C. State Highway Depâ€™t, 237 S.C. 584, 588, 118 S.E.2d 322, 323 (1961).Â  Every natural
  consequence which flows from the initial injury, unless the result of an
  independent intervening cause sufficient to sever the chain of causation, is
  also compensable.Â  Whitfield v. Daniel Constr. Co., 226 S.C. 37, 40-41,
  83 S.E.2d 460, 462 (1954).Â  Further, â€œ[c]ircumstantial evidence . . . need not
  reach such a degree of certainty as to exclude every reasonable or possible
  conclusion other than that reached.â€Â  Id. at 43, 83 S.E.2d at 463-64 (internal
  quotation and citation omitted).
Both sides concede Waxenfelter sustained a change of condition for the worse under section
  42-17-90.Â  Consequently, the issue before this Court is whether the spinal
  infection severed the causal relationship between the initial injury and
  subsequent injury to a degree that would preclude Waxenfelter from receiving
  benefits.Â  We find substantial evidence exists to support the Commissionâ€™s award. 
 
Waxenfelter
  testified that his back injury had gradually worsened from the initial injury
  in April 2003.Â  His pain was â€œlow level and manageableâ€ in late 2003, but it
  was â€œoff the scaleâ€ by May 2004.Â  Further, the medical evidence presented by
  Waxenfelter, as well as the deposition testimony of Dr. Poletti, reinforces
  that his worsening of condition was a natural progression from his initial
  compensable injury. Â Dr. Poletti testified that regardless of Waxenfelterâ€™s
  spinal infection, he was certain his condition had worsened since 2003.Â  Dr.
  Poletti also testified the abscess plausibly was a result of the work-related
  hernia, which progressively worsened over time into the abscess, or the abscess
  developed as a result of Waxenfelterâ€™s medical treatment for the hernia.Â 
  Additionally, Dr. Wilkins opined in May 2004 that Waxenfelterâ€™s disc herniation
  was related to his previous work-related injury.Â  Consequently, Waxenfelter
  presented substantial evidence that his worsening of condition was causally
  related to his initial injury and was not severed by his ensuing back
  infection.Â  In viewing the record as a whole, we find the Commissionâ€™s award is
  justified.  
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s ruling is Â 
AFFIRMED.[2]
ANDERSON
  and WILLIAMS, JJ., and CURETON, AJ., concur.

[1]Â  The Single Commissioner did not hold Wal-Mart
  responsible for treatment costs related to Waxenfelterâ€™s emergency surgery in
  July 2004, and Waxenfelter did not appeal this ruling.Â   
[2] We decide this case without oral arguments pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Richardson v. Lee County School District
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR
  RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2),
  SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Wallace H.
      Richardson, Sr., Respondent,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Lee County School District, Employer, and South Carolina School Boards Insurance Trust, Carrier, Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal From Lee County
Â Clifton Newman, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-076
Submitted December 1, 2007 â€“ Filed
  February 4, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Adrianne L. Turner, of Columbia, for
  Appellants.
				E. W. Cromartie, II, of Columbia, for Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  In
  this workersâ€™ compensation action, Lee County School District (School District) appeals the award of benefits to Dr. Wallace Richardson, contending (1)
  the work-related accident on which Richardsonâ€™s claim was based did not result
  in any permanent injury; (2) Richardson was not permanently and totally
  disabled; and (3) Richardsonâ€™s unjustified refusal to undergo surgery made him
  ineligible for benefits.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
 
FACTS
Richardson had taught school for thirty years.Â  At the time of his accident, he was a
  science teacher with School District at Lee County Middle School. Â On October
  16, 2002, while Richardson was attending a school staff conference, the wicker
  chair in which he was sitting collapsed, causing him to fall backwards onto his
  back and hips and hit his shoulder.Â  As a result of the accident, Richardson sustained substantial injuries to his back and hips, as well as injuries to his
  head, shoulders, elbows, wrists, and neck.Â   
Before the
  incident, Richardson suffered from degenerative joint disease and arthritis for
  which he sought treatment from Dr. Williams, his regular physician.Â  Just two
  days before the accident, Richardson, on a referral from Dr. Williams,
  consulted Dr. Ervin, an orthopedic physician in Florence, who determined Richardson was suffering from severe degenerative disease of both hips and advised Richardson he would eventually have to undergo replacement of both hips.Â  Richardson was also an overweight smoker and suffered from chronic bronchitis and sleep
  apnea.Â   
After the accident, Dr. Williams treated Richardsonâ€™s leg and hip
  pain.Â  On November 4, 2002, Richardson consulted Dr. Ervin, who wrote in his
  notes that he anticipated Richardson would suffer no permanent impairment from
  his fall and recommended that Richardson follow through with the physical
  therapy prescribed by Dr.Williams.Â  On Dr. Williamsâ€™s advice, Richardson
  underwent physical therapy at Tuomey Rehabilitation Center in Sumter.Â  After three weeks, however, Richardson found no
  improvement in his condition and stopped treatment.Â   
Richardson notified School District and timely filed a workersâ€™ compensation claim.Â  On
  December 20, 2004, the single commissioner held a hearing and found Richardson suffered a compensable injury by accident arising out of and in the course of
  his employment that left him permanently and totally disabled from a
  combination of injuries to his back, legs, and hips.Â  School District, along
  with its insurance company, applied to the appellate panel for review of the single
  commissionerâ€™s findings.Â  The appellate panel unanimously affirmed the order of
  the single commissioner.Â  Thereafter, the circuit court affirmed the appellate panelâ€™s
  order and denied School Districtâ€™s motion to alter or amend. Â This appeal
  followed.Â   
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œThe
  Administrative Procedures Act establishes the standard of review for decisions
  by the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.â€ Â Forrest v. A.S.
    Price Mechanical, 373 S.C. 303, 306, 644 S.E.2d 784, 785 (Ct. App. 2007) (citing Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 134-35, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981)). Â â€œIn
  workersâ€™ compensation cases, the Full Commission is the ultimate fact finder.â€ Â Shealy
    v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 455, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000) (citation
  omitted). Â This Court reviews facts based on the substantial evidence standard.
  Â Thompson v. S.C. Steel Erectors, 369 S.C. 606, 612, 632 S.E.2d 874, 877
  (Ct. App. 2006). Â â€œUnder the substantial evidence standard, the appellate court
  may not substitute its judgment for that of the Commission as to the weight of
  the evidence on questions of fact.â€ Â Forrest, 373 S.C. at 306, 644
  S.E.2d at 785 (citing S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5) (Supp. 2006)). Â â€œSubstantial
  evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence nor evidence viewed from one side,
  but such evidence, when the whole record is considered, as would allow reasonable
  minds to reach the conclusion the Full Commission reached.â€ Â Shealy, 341
  S.C. at 455, 535 S.E.2d at 442.
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â  School District first
  contends Richardsonâ€™s condition existed before his accident and he therefore was
  not entitled to workersâ€™ compensation benefits. Â We disagree.Â   
The aggravation
  of a pre-existing condition that leads to disability or death is compensable
  under the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.Â  See Glover v.
    Columbia Hosp. of Richland County, 236 S.C. 410, 419, 114 S.E.2d 565, 569
  (1960) (stating a claimantâ€™s pre-existing disease or infirmity does not
  disqualify a workersâ€™ compensation claim if the claimantâ€™s work aggravated,
  accelerated, or combined with the disease or infirmity to cause the condition
  for which compensation is sought); Holly v. Spartan Grain Mill & Co.,
  210 S.C. 183, 189, 42 S.E.2d 59, 62 (1947) (â€œWhere a previously diseased
  condition is aggravated by injury or accident arising out of or in the course
  of employment, and this results in . . . disability, there is a compensable
  injury.â€); Anderson v. Baptist Med. Ctr., 343 S.C. 487, 493, 541 S.E.2d
  526, 528 (2001) (â€œThe right of a claimant to compensation for aggravation of a
  pre-existing condition arises only where there is a dormant condition which has
  produced no disability but which becomes disabling by reason of the aggravating
  injury.â€); Mullinax v. Winn-Dixie Stores, Inc., 318 S.C. 431, 437, 458
  S.E.2d 76, 79 (Ct. App. 1995) (â€œ[A] work-related accident which aggravates or
  accelerates a pre-existing condition, infirmity, or disease is . . .
  compensable.â€).
School
  District asserts Richardsonâ€™s hip problems were caused by years of obesity and
  the stress of being a professional football player.Â  Although Richardson
  himself acknowledged he had been a large man his whole life and played both
  college and professional football, we cannot, under our standard of review,
  disregard the substantial evidence of record that Richardsonâ€™s present
  complaints resulted from his workplace accident rather than his prior physical
  condition.Â  This evidence consists of both lay and professional testimony.
At
  the hearing before the single commissioner, Richardson testified about
  differences in his physical abilities before and after his accident.Â  He stated
  that, although he did not need a cane before his accident, he now cannot walk
  or stand up from a sitting position without one.Â  Before his injury, in
  addition to working full time with School District, he was a pastor to three
  church congregations, but can no longer continue any of these activities.Â  Since
  the accident, he has been unable to help his wife with cleaning, shopping, and
  other household activities.Â  Furthermore, Richardson testified he experienced a
  weaker physical state even with his medication use.Â  In addition, Richardsonâ€™s wife testified on his behalf and supported his assertions.Â  
 
The
  record also has medical evidence that Richardsonâ€™s accident resulted in a
  compensable injury.Â  Although Dr. Ervin initially anticipated no permanent
  impairment as a result of the incident, he later stated he did not feel Richardson would be able to continue with his job as a school teacher and assigned him a
  forty-percent impairment rating for each hip.Â  Significantly, in his
  deposition, Dr. Ervin, in responding to a question from Richardsonâ€™s attorney
  regarding his opinion as to whether Richardsonâ€™s fall aggravated his
  pre-existing degenerative disease, stated â€œthereâ€™s no question about it.â€Â  
 
2.Â  School District next
  argues Richardson failed to meet his burden of proving a loss of earning
  capacity under the workersâ€™ compensation statutes.Â  In support of this
  argument, School District contends Richardson is qualified and capable of
  retaining a high earning capacity in an administrative position despite his
  accident.Â  We decline to address this argument.
We
  have reviewed the record on appeal and found no indication that School District either raised this issue to the appellate panel or presented it in its
  petition for judicial review; therefore, this issue is not preserved for our
  review. Â Although this issue may have been referenced in School Districtâ€™s
  motion under Rule 59(e), the motion cannot cure the failure to timely raise it
  to the appropriate tribunal. Â See Hickman v. Hickman, 301 S.C.
  455, 456, 392 S.E.2d 481, 482 (Ct. App. 1990) (â€œA party cannot use Rule 59(e)
  to present to the court an issue the party could have raised prior to judgment
  but did not.â€).
3.Â  Finally, School District
  argues that, pursuant to South Carolina Code section 42-15-60, Richardson should have been ordered to forfeit his benefits because he refused reasonable
  medical treatment.Â  In support of this argument, School District appears to assert
  that Richardson, in refusing to lose weight and continuing to smoke, has
  without good cause made himself unable to undergo recommended hip replacement
  surgery to improve his condition.Â  We disagree.Â   
Section
  42-15-60 provides in pertinent part as follows:  

	The
  refusal of an employee to accept any medical, hospital, surgical or other
  treatment when provided by the employer or ordered by the Commission shall bar such employee from further compensation until such refusal ceases and
  no compensation shall at any time be paid for the period of suspension unless
  in the opinion of the Commission the circumstances justified the refusal, in
  which case the Commission may order a change in the medical or hospital service.

S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-60 (1985) (emphasis added).
In finding
  Richardson was justified in â€œrefusingâ€ bilateral hip arthroplasty surgery, the
  single commissioner, affirmed by the appellate panel and the circuit court, cited
  not only the risks of the surgery but also the absence of any request by School
  District that Richardson undergo such an operation.Â  School District does not
  allege it ever offered, much less provided, such a procedure.Â  Under these
  circumstances, we hold section 42-15-60 does not apply to the present case.Â  Regardless
  of whether Richardsonâ€™s failure to lose weight and stop smoking could constitute
  an unjustified refusal of recommended treatment, the fact that this treatment
  was neither provided by School District nor ordered by the Workersâ€™
  Compensation Commission prevents this failure from making him ineligible for
  benefits.
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J.,
  KITTREDGE and THOMAS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Robert Orlando Hill, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Abbeville County
Wyatt T. Saunders, Jr, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-081
Submitted February 1, 2008 â€“ Filed
  February 6, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Appellate Defender Eleanor D. Cleary, of Columbia and Ernest
  Charles Grose, Jr., of Greenwood, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant
  Attorney General Shawn L. Reeves, all of Columbia; Â and Solicitor Jerry W. Peace,
  of Greenwood, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: In
  July 2005, Robert Orlando Hill (Hill) was convicted of voluntary manslaughter
  and possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime. He was
  sentenced to a total of thirty-five years in prison. Â Hill appeals this
  conviction contending the trial court erred by refusing to admit testimony
  regarding prior threats in connection with the deceased victim.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS  
Appellant
  Hill was charged with shooting Artell Hill[2] (Artie) while Artie sat in the
  passenger seat of a parked car. Â The shooting occurred shortly after Odell Tillman, Jeffrey Tatum, and Artie rode in Tillmanâ€™s
  car to Eastgate Apartments in Calhoun Falls. Â Tillman parked the car and
  entered an apartment while Tatum exited the rear of the car and stood next to
  the passenger side window to talk to Artie.Â  Shortly thereafter, Hill rode into
  the Eastgate Apartmentsâ€™ parking lot on a bike. 
At trial the State presented testimony from five witnesses who
  were present at the shooting.[3]Â 
  Hill and three of the Stateâ€™s witnesses testified Tatum said, â€œWhatâ€™s up?â€ to
  Hill as he rode into the parking lot. Â Hill responded, â€œNothing,â€ at which
  point Artie said â€œ I heard you been looking for me,â€ to Hill. Â Two witnesses
  testified Hill responded, â€œStay right there,â€ as he disembarked from the bike,
  walked towards the parked car, pulled his shirt up, removed a gun from his
  pants, and shot Artie six times. 
Hill testified he began shooting when he saw Artie reach over as
  though he were going to open the car door. Â None of the Stateâ€™s five witnesses
  saw Artie move towards the car door or attempt to open the car door. Â Hill
  also testified Artie had raised a stick-like bat towards him. Â After the
  shooting Artie was found clasping a stick-like bat, however, witnesses never saw
  the stick until after Artie had been shot. 
Hill shot Artie six times, including four shots to the head. Â After
  the shooting, Hill got back onto his bike and rode away. Â He turned himself
  into the police the following morning. Hill was indicted for murder and
  possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime. Â During
  his July 2005[4] trial, Hill admitted to shooting Artie but claimed he did so in self-defense as
  he felt he was in danger. Â A jury found Hill guilty of voluntary manslaughter
  and possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime. Â Hill appeals. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In
  criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.Â  State
    v. Baccus, 367 S.C. 41, 48, 625 S.E.2d 216, 220 (2006).Â  An appellate
  court is bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly
  erroneous.Â  Id.Â  This same standard of review applies to a trial courtâ€™s
  determination of the admissibility of certain evidence in criminal cases.Â  State
    v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â  â€œThe admission or
  exclusion of evidence is a matter addressed to the sound discretion of the
  trial court and its ruling will not be disturbed in the absence of a manifest
  abuse of discretion accompanied by probable prejudice.â€ State v. Wise,
  359 S.C. 14, 21, 596 S.E.2d 475, 478 (2004).

LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Shannon
  Hillâ€™s Testimony
At trial Hill unsucessfully sought to introduce testimony from
  Shannon Hill[5] (Shannon) that she had heard of Artie chasing her brother with a stick-like
  bat. Â Since Shannon had no
  first hand knowledge of the incident, the trial court sustained a hearsay
  objection. Â Hill then proffered Shannonâ€™s testimony from his first trial in
  which Shannon testified she heard Artie had chased her brother with a bat but
  denied that Artie frequently carried bats. Â Hill argues Shannonâ€™s testimony
  regarding this incident should have been admitted into evidence as he could have
  taken it into account when he decided to defend himself by shooting Artie.Â  We
  disagree. 
â€œIn the murder prosecution of one pleading self-defense against an
  attack by the deceased, evidence of other specific instances of violence on the
  part of the deceased are not admissible unless they were directed against the
  defendant or, if directed against others, were so closely connected at point of
  time or occasion with the homicide as reasonably to indicate the state of mind
  of the deceased at the time of the homicide, or to produce reasonable apprehension of great bodily harm.â€ State
    v. Day, 341 S.C. 410, 419-420, 535 S.E.2d 431, 436 (2000).Â  Whether a
  specific instance of conduct by the deceased is so closely connected in time as
  to be admissible is in the trial court's discretion and will not be disturbed
  on appeal absent an abuse of discretion. Id. at 420, 535 S.E.2d at 436.
In this instance, Artie was allegedly violent toward Shannonâ€™s brother, not Hill.Â  The record fails to state when the incident took place or how
  it was closely connected with the shooting.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial
  court did not err in refusing to admit testimony from Shannon regarding an
  incident between her brother and Artie.Â  
II.  Appellant
  Hillâ€™s Testimony
The trial court refused to allow Hill to testify that Artieâ€™s
  friend, Sammy, had sent word through Artieâ€™s girlfriend, Glenrissa, that when
  Sammy saw Hill, Sammy â€œwas going to handle the business.â€ Â Hill argues this
  testimony should have been admitted to illustrate he believed Artie had
  threatened him and show Hillâ€™s state of mind when he shot Artie.Â  We disagree.
At trial Hill testified to prior threats from Artie. Â Hill also
  recounted an incident in which a bunch of their peers were chasing each other
  with stick-like bats and Artie hit the car Hill was in, denting it twice. Â Hill
  further testified that Artie and Sammy conveyed threats to him through other
  people which caused Hill to avoid being in close proximity with Artie. Â After
  the trial court would not allow further testimony regarding instances in which
  Hill learned of threats through a third person, Hill proffered the following
  testimony:

	Q: When you were testifying in front of the jury, I asked you
  about having received threats through other people, right?
	A: Yes, sir.
	Q: And you were getting ready to talk about something that Sammy
  had said to you?
	A: Yes, sir.
	Q: All right.Â  What was it that Sammy had said to you?
	A: Sammy had sent word from Glenrissa Gates, Artieâ€™s girlfriend at
  the time, that when he seen me, me and him was going one on one, when he see
  me, he was going to handle the business.
	Q: Who did you understand was going to handle the business?
	A: Sammy at the time, that is what he said.
	Q: About who?
	A: About me, sent the word, tell me that.
	Q: Who sent the word?
	A: Sammy.
	Q: All right.Â  Was Artie connected with that?
	A: Yes, sir.
	Q: How was Artie connected with that?
	A: Well, Artie and Sammy, they were like best friends.
	Q: Okay.Â  And who were you worried about handling the business
  with you?
	A: Well, Artieâ€¦.

It is a well-settled rule that in homicide cases, the defendant is
  permitted to introduce testimony concerning previous difficulties with the
  decedent.Â  State v. Atchison, 268 S.C. 588, 593, 235 S.E.2d 294, 296
  (1977).Â  â€œThe rationale for allowing such evidence is that it is relevant to
  the issue of the animus of the parties as it relates to the demeanor each party had reason to expect from the other
  when they met at the time of the fatal difficulty.â€ Id. at 593-94, 235
  S.E.2d at 296.Â  
In this instance, Hill is attempting to introduce testimony
  concerning a threat from a friend of the decedent, not Artie himself.Â  The admission or exclusion of evidence is within the
  discretion of the trial court and will not be reversed absent an abuse of
  discretion.Â  State v. Saltz, 346 S.C. 114, 121, 551 S.E.2d 240,
  244 (2001).Â  We find no such abuse occurred by refusing to admit Hillâ€™s
  testimony regarding a threat from Sammy delivered via Glenrissa.Â  Although
  Sammy was Artieâ€™s friend, Sammy was not present at or in anyway involved with
  the shooting.Â  In addition, we note the record already contained evidence of Artieâ€™s
  direct threats towards Hill. Â Any error in excluding
  Hillâ€™s testimony regarding Sammyâ€™s threat was harmless and could not have
  reasonably affected the result of the trial since evidence of Artieâ€™s threats was
  already in the record. State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 380-81, 580 S.E.2d
  785, 795 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  
Accordingly, the trial court is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, SHORT, and THOMAS, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] The victim, Artell Hill, is not related to Appellant
  Robert Orlando Hill.  
[3] Although the testimony of the five witnesses varies
  depending on what each heard Hill, Tatum, and Artie say, all agree on the
  pattern of events preceding the shooting.
[4] The trial held in July 2005 was Hillâ€™s second trial.
  Hillâ€™s first conviction was reversed after a successful appeal regarding the
  Stateâ€™s comments on Hillâ€™s post-arrest silence. See State v. Hill,
  360 S.C. 13, 598 S.E.2d 732 (Ct. App. 2004).
[5] The witness, Shannon Hill, is not related to
  Appellant Robert Orlando Hill or the victim, Artell Hill.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        White Hat
          Properties, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        The Town of Hilton Head Island, and The Town of Hilton Head Island Board of Zoning Appeals, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County

  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-082
