  February 6, 2008
  Withdrawn and Substituted April 28, 2008

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        James O. Hale, of Hilton Head Island, for Appellant.
        Gregory M. Alford, of Hilton Head Island, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â 
  White Hat appealed Hilton Headâ€™s order to stop construction of residential
  homes on Lot 142 of Sea Pines Plantation to the Board of Zoning Appeals (BZA).Â 
  The BZA found Lot 142 was designated as golf course or if undesignated, open
  space, and affirmed the stop work order.Â  The
  circuit court, sitting in its appellate capacity, affirmed.Â  White Hat appeals,
  and we affirm.
1. White
  Hat argues the circuit court erred by deferring to the BZAâ€™s findings as the
  BZA interpreted an ordinance.Â  We disagree and find the BZAâ€™s findings were factual,
  warranting deference from the circuit court and this court. 
The
  factual findings of a BZA will
  not be disturbed, unless there is no evidence to support the findings.Â  Vulcan
    Materials Co. v. Greenville County Bd. of Zoning Appeals, 342
  S.C. 480, 488, 536 S.E.2d 892, 896 (Ct. Ap. 2000).Â  Conversely,
  the BZAâ€™s ruling will not be upheld if an error of law exists or if the BZA
  acted arbitrarily or unreasonably.Â  Peterson Outdoor Adver. v. City of Myrtle Beach, 327 S.C. 230, 235, 489 S.E.2d 630, 633 (1997).Â  Â Â 
In this
  case, the BZA found â€œthis property is a portion of the Golf Course and was
  designated as a golf course use.â€Â  The BZA went on to find if the designation
  was uncertain, then â€œit should be found as undesignated and, therefore, open
  space.â€Â  We hold this determination is factual, supported by some evidence, and
  neither arbitrary nor unreasonable.
The 1984 Master Plan of Sea Pines is devoid of any reference to Lot 142, the piece of property this case involves.Â  Lot 142 was created after 1984.Â  Lot
  142 appeared in December 1999, when a Settlement Agreement granted Lot 142 by quitclaim deed to Sea Pines
  Land Company, which later became known as White Hat.Â  Also in December 1999,
  Hilton Head issued subdivision approval for Lot 142.Â  However, neither of these
  actions amended the Master Plan, which was necessary to change zoning.
Before
  the BZA, Hilton Headâ€™s Urban Designer stated Lot 142, under the Land Use Map,
  was part of the golf course, which is nonresidential.Â  The Designer further
  informed the BZA that he determined the property was undesignated.Â  We believe
  there is evidence to support the BZAâ€™s finding.
White
  Hat attempts to expand this courtâ€™s scope of review by arguing the BZAâ€™s
  determination was legal, not factual.Â  White Hat points to Hilton Head Land Management Ordinance
  section 16-4-209(D) (1993), which states, â€œUndesignated areas on these master
  plans shall be considered as open space.â€Â  This argument is faulty, as the
  BZAâ€™s finding hinges on its factual determination the land was golf course or
  undesignated, not any perceived application of the ordinance.
This
  court acknowledges the ostensible unfairness created by the stop work order, but the standard of review restrains this court to defer
  to the BZAâ€™s judgment on factual findings regarding zoning.Â  See Clear
    Channel Outdoor v. City of Myrtle Beach, 372 S.C. 230, 234, 642 S.E.2d 565,
  567 (2007) (â€œA court will refrain from substituting its judgment for that
  of the reviewing body, even if it disagrees with the decision.â€).Â  Moreover,
  this seeming inequity may be attributed in part to White Hatâ€™s own conduct.Â  As
  the circuit court noted, White Hatâ€™s losses due to the stop work order flow
  directly from White Hatâ€™s continued representation the 1999 Settlement
  Agreement authorized the building of two houses on Lot 142, which it did not.Â 
  As noted above, an amendment to the Master Plan was necessary to affect a
  zoning change.Â  In this regard, White Hatâ€™s proper
  remedy is to apply for a zoning map amendment.Â  See Hilton Head Land Management Ordinance Â§16-3-1608 (1998).
2. White
  Hat additionally contends the BZA denied White Hatâ€™s due process rights to
  develop its case.Â  We disagree.
Under South Carolina jurisprudence, due process
  requires â€œ(1) adequate notice; (2) adequate opportunity for a hearing; (3) the
  right to introduce evidence; and (4) the right to confront and cross-examine
  witnesses.â€Â  Clear Channel, 372 S.C. at 235, 642 S.E.2d at 567.Â  In Clear
    Channel, the South Carolina Supreme Court found the partyâ€™s due process
  rights were not violated because the party had notice of the nonconformity
  issue and an opportunity to be heard.Â  372 S.C. at 235, 642 S.E.2d at 568.
In the case at
  hand, the stop work order was issued on September 14, 2004.Â  White Hat appealed
  the order to the BZA on September 28, 2004.Â  The BZA conducted two hearings
  regarding the order, both of which White Hatâ€™s counsel attended.Â  At the second
  hearing, White Hatâ€™s counsel made a presentation to the BZA.Â  Therefore, White
  Hat had notice of the issue regarding Lot 142â€™s zoning and an opportunity to be
  heard.Â  Thus, White Hatâ€™s due process rights were not violated.
3. White
  Hat next argues Hilton Head should be estopped from denying Lot 142 is zoned
  residential.Â  We disagree.
In order to claim equitable estoppel, a party must
  illustrate: â€œ(1) a lack of knowledge and the means of knowledge of truth as to
  facts in question; (2) justifiable reliance upon the conduct of the party
  estopped; and (3) prejudicial change in the position of the party claiming
  estoppel.â€Â  Clear Channel, 372 S.C. at 235, 642 S.E.2d at 568.Â  
In Clear
  Channel, Clear Channel applied for a permit to replace a billboard, which
  was completely destroyed by a tornado.Â  372 S.C. at 232, 642 S.E.2d at 566.Â 
  The Zoning Administrator denied the permit because of a zoning ordinance
  prohibiting the construction of new billboards, and the cityâ€™s BZA upheld the
  denial.Â  Id.Â  Clear Channelâ€™s previous billboard did not conform;
  however, Clear Channel argued the city was estopped from arguing nonconformity
  because the city inspected the previous billboard and found it did conform.Â  Id. at 235, 642 S.E.2d at 568.Â  The South Carolina Supreme Court rejected Clear
  Channelâ€™s argument stating, Clear Channel is â€œin the business of
  outdoor advertising and had ample means of knowing its sign violated the Cityâ€™s ordinance.â€Â  Id. at 235-36, 642 S.E.2d at 568.Â  Further, Clear Channel knew or had means to know
  its sign was nonconforming under the city ordinance.Â  Id. at 236, 642
  S.E.2d at 568.Â  Therefore, Clear Channelâ€™s â€œreliance on the doctrine of
  estoppel is misplaced.â€Â  Id. 
This
  caseâ€™s facts fit squarely with Clear Channel.Â  White Hat had ample means
  of knowing (especially from Hilton Head Land Management Ordinance section
  16-3-1608) the only way to affect zoning was to change the Master Plan through
  a zoning map amendment, despite Hilton Headâ€™s improper issuance of a building
  permit.Â  Accordingly, Hilton Head is not estopped from denying Lot 142 is residential.
4. Finally,
  White Hat asserts Hilton Headâ€™s adoption of the 1993 amendment to section
  16-4-209 of Hilton Head Land Management Ordinance, which made undesignated land
  open space, is void for lack of notice.Â  We disagree.
In
  1993, the applicable law barred a challenge to an amendment of a zoning
  regulation more than two years after the public hearing for inadequacy of
  notice, if substantial compliance with notice requirements existed.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 6-7-730 (Supp. 1994).[1]Â 
  Section 6-7-730 mandated the governing authority to hold advertised, public
  hearings regarding the amendment.
The
  record does indicate eight public hearings were conducted and a First and
  Second reading by the town council prior to the adoption of the 1993
  amendment.Â  Additionally, the record includes two newspaper clippings
  advertising the public hearings.Â  Therefore, this argument is without merit
  because it falls after the two-year statue of limitations and the record
  provides evidence of proper notice.Â  
White
  Hat heavily relied on Brown v. County of Charleston, 303 S.C. 245, 247,
  399 S.E.2d 784, 785-86 (Ct. App. 1990), where this court held the notice of an
  amendment did not sufficiently notify landowners the use of their own property
  would be altered, even though no one contested the advertisementâ€™s compliance
  with the statutory guidelines.Â  Brown is easily distinguished from the
  case at hand as the amendment in this case did not change a current landownerâ€™s
  property rights.Â  Instead, the ordinance attempted to bring continuity to the
  subdivision by designating uncertain land as open space.Â  Additionally, as in Clear
    Channel, White Hat is in the land development business and should have
  known the potential implications of the amendment.Â  372 S.C. at 236, 642 S.E.2d at 568.
During
  oral argument, White Hat asserted an unconstitutional taking occurred; however,
  this issue was not ruled upon below or advanced in White Hatâ€™s brief.[2]Â 
  Therefore, under issue preservation principles, this argument is not properly
  before us.Â  See Lucas v. Rawl Family Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 359 S.C. 505,
  510-11, 598 S.E.2d 712, 715 (2004) (â€œIt is well settled that, but for a
  very few exceptional circumstances, an appellate court cannot address an issue
  unless it was raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.â€). 
CONCLUSION
Although White Hat attempts to disguise the BZAâ€™s
  factual determinations as legal, our standard of review requires this court to
  defer to the BZAâ€™s factual findings.Â  Further, White Hatâ€™s due process,
  estoppel, and public notice arguments lack merit.Â  Accordingly, the BZAâ€™s order
  is 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE and THOMAS, JJ., concur.


[1]Â  The
  current law limits the statute of limitations to sixty days after the decision
  of the governing body.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 6-29-760(D) (2004).
[2]Â  The last sentence of White Hatâ€™s reply brief referred
  to a â€œconstitutionally inappropriate taking;â€ however, this mere mention of a
  taking is conclusory.Â  See Glasscock, Inc. v. U.S. Fid. and Guar. Co., 348 S.C. 76, 81, 557 S.E.2d 689, 691 (Ct. App. 2001) (stating
  â€œshort, conclusory statements made without supporting authority are deemed
  abandoned on appeal and therefore not presented for reviewâ€).

THIS
  OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
  PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Midland Parkway Associates, LLP, Appellant,
				v.
				George Touras,
      Equity Properties and Development Company, Wilmington Trust Company, as
      Trustee for Southland-Summerville W. D. Delaware Business Trust, and
      Principal Mutual Life Insurance Company, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Dorchester County
Â James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-083
Submitted December 1, 2007 â€“ Filed
  February 6, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				William C. Cleveland, of Charleston, for Appellant.
				Michael A. Scardato, Robert L. Widener, both of Charleston; Michael
  Sher, of Chicago, for Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Midland
  Parkway Associates, LLP (Midland) brought this action against George Touras, Equity Properties and
  Development Company, Wilmington Trust Company, as Trustee for
  Southland-Summerville W. D. Delaware Business Trust, and Principal Mutual Life
  Insurance Company (collectively Wilmington).Â  Midland sought specific
  performance of an alleged oral agreement to convey real estate between Midland and Wilmington.Â  The trial court granted summary judgment in favor of Wilmington on Midlandâ€™s causes of action for breach of contract, fraudulent
  misrepresentation, violation of the South Carolina Unfair Trade Practices Act
  (UTPA), and promissory estoppel.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Robert Irick is
  the managing partner of Midland.[2] Â In July of 1999, Midland purchased a parcel of land located in Summerville, South Carolina (Midland Parcel).Â  Following the closing, Midland constructed an
  apartment complex on the Midland Parcel.
During construction,
  Midland discovered a water problem on the Midland Parcel. Â According to Midland, water migrated onto the Midland Parcel from an adjacent property leased by
  Winn-Dixie and owned by Wilmington.Â  The migrating water allegedly caused
  damage to the Midland Parcel including a snake infestation and â€œbubblingâ€ of
  the asphalt parking lot.
On September 27, 2001, Irick sent a letter
  to Wilmingtonâ€™s counsel, Douglas Lubelchek, proposing: (1) Wilmington deed
  Midland .878 acres of property leased by Winn-Dixie; (2) Midland accept the
  drainage and bear any expense of additional drainage construction; (3) Midland ensure
  zoning would not be adversely affected; and (4) Midland indemnify Wilmington for
  any damage.Â  Midland sent a similar letter to a Winn-Dixie representative, who
  orally agreed to â€œencourage [Wilmington] to cooperate with [Midland].â€Â  Irick and Lubelchek engaged in several phone calls, and according
  to Irick, they reached an oral agreement to the conveyance of the property.Â  Irick
  allegedly asked Lubelchek, â€œto make [it] clear . . . what needs to be done, [to]
  put [it] in writing and . . . [Lubelcheck] said that he would.â€Â  Irick believed
  this conversation occurred sometime in February
  of 2002.Â  The only writing
  evidencing the alleged agreement is a February 19, 2002 letter from Lubelchek
  to Irick stating:Â  Â 

	[p]ursuant to our conversations regarding the wetland area owned
  by [Wilmington] . . . this letter will confirm the partiesâ€™ understanding
  regarding the conveyance of a portion of the wetland area to Midland. 
	Owner will consider conveying . . . .878 acres . . .
  provided the following conditions are satisfied prior to the conveyance, all at
  Midlandâ€™s sole cost and expense; if any . . . . 

(emphasis
  added).Â  In the letter, Wilmington enumerated conditions precedent to any
  conveyance including: (1) Wilmington
  obtains all necessary consents from its lender; (2) Wilmington obtains
  necessary waivers from Winn-Dixie; (3) Midland prepares and submits all plans
  and plats; (4) Midland prepares an easement; (5) Midland obtains all permits or
  approvals; (6) Midland cooperates with regard to any zoning changes; (7)
  Midland bears all costs, including attorney fees; and (8) Midland obtains
  approval from the City of Summerville regarding zoning.
Irick believed this letter constituted a binding and enforceable
  agreement between Midland and Wilmington requiring Wilmington to convey the
  wetland and border parcels if the conditions precedent were met. 
Following the Irick/Lubelchek telephone conversation, but prior to
  the February 19 letter, Irick informed his attorney, Lewis Horton, that Midland and Wilmington had resolved the drainage problem.Â  After Horton reviewed the
  February 19 letter, however, he told Irick the letter did not indicate an
  â€œunequivocal commitmentâ€ to convey and the letter did not â€œdovetail, so to
  speakâ€ with Irickâ€™s description of the agreement.Â  
Thereafter, Horton sent Lubelchek a letter requesting confirmation
  of the oral agreement.Â  In Hortonâ€™s August 28, 2002 letter, he requested Lubelchek
  â€œadvise immediately of its intentionâ€ and to proceed to address the conditions
  precedent required to be performed by Wilmington.Â  Horton recalled one
  follow-up telephone conversation with Lubelchek, but received no responsive correspondence.
Subsequently, Horton communicated with Jennifer Desser, Lubelcheckâ€™s
  associate. Â By e-mail dated October 9, 2002, Dresser informed Lubelchek of her
  continuing conversations with Irick and described the February 19 letter as
  â€œsetting forth conditions to [Wilmingtonâ€™s] willingness to convey the
  property.â€Â  
By later dated November 8, 2002, Horton requested a response from Wilmington within ten days.Â  The record does not reflect a response. Â In a later e-mail to
  Lubelchek, Horton made no mention of Midlandâ€™s desire to obtain the wetland and
  border parcels, but requested a â€œletter [from Wilmington] committing to handle
  the surface water nuisance problem currently existing on [its] property.â€[3]
After receiving no response from Wilmingtonâ€™s counsel on either
  the proposed conveyance or the drainage problem, Horton e-mailed Lubelchek and
  requested an immediate response, asking whether Wilmington would:Â  

	1. Convey the property in satisfaction of any and all claims as
  originally discussed.
	2. Convey the property for consideration including satisfaction of
  any and all claims.
	3. Give a commitment to handle the surface water drainage problem
  on [Wilmingtonâ€™s] property so as to allow [Midland] to build a maximum of 48
  additional units on their own property.
	4. Ignore the problem . . . .

Once again Wilmington did not respond and Midland filed this action alleging, inter alia,
  breach of contract, fraudulent misrepresentation, violation of the UTPA, and
  promissory estoppel.Â  The trial court granted Wilmington summary judgment on
  all causes of action.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the
  grant of a summary judgment motion, appellate courts apply the same standard governing
  the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  Walsh v. Woods, 371 S.C. 319,
  324, 638 S.E2d 85, 88 (Ct. App. 2006). Â Summary judgment is proper when there
  is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to
  judgment as a matter of law.Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  On appeal from an order
  granting summary judgment, the appellate court will review all ambiguities,
  conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence in a light most
  favorable to the non-moving party below.Â  Willis v. Wu, 362 S.C. 146,
  151, 607 S.E.2d 63, 65 (2004).
LAW/ANALYSIS

I.  Existence of Valid
  and Enforceable Agreement
Midland contends
  the trial court erred in finding as a matter of law that no valid, enforceable contract
  existed.Â  We disagree.Â  
The essential
  terms of a contract are offer, acceptance of the offer, and valuable consideration.Â  Sauner v. Pub. Serv. Auth. of South Carolina, 354 S.C. 397, 406, 581
  S.E.2d 161, 166 (2003).Â  In order to have a valid and enforceable contract,
  there must be a meeting of the minds between the parties with regard to all
  essential and material terms of the agreement.Â  Patricia Grand Hotel v.
    MacGuire Enters., 372 S.C. 634, 638, 643 S.E.2d 692, 694 (Ct. App. 2007). Â The
  â€œmeeting of the mindsâ€ requirement cannot be met by the â€œsecret purpose or
  intention on the part of one of the parties, stored away in his mind and not
  brought to the attention of the other party, but must be based on purpose and
  intention which has been made known or which, from all the circumstances,
  should be known.â€Â  Player v. Chandler, 299 S.C. 101, 105, 382 S.E.2d 891,
  894 (1989).Â  Â Â 
The record before
  us evinces no meeting of the minds between Midland and Wilmington.Â  There is no
  indication essential terms were discussed. Instead, there is only Irickâ€™s belief
  that a verbal understanding was reached and a letter from Wilmingtonâ€™s counsel
  stating Wilmington would â€œconsiderâ€ conveying the wetland parcel provided
  certain conditions were satisfied.Â  Furthermore, Midlandâ€™s own attorney
  counseled Irick that the February 19 letter was not an â€œunequivocal commitmentâ€
  to convey.Â  We agree the February 19 letter does not contain the essential
  terms of a contract and find no error in the trial courtâ€™s legal finding that
  no contract existed.
II.  Statute of Frauds
Midland Parkway argues
  the trial court erred in finding the statute of frauds barred the enforcement
  of any oral agreement.Â  We disagree.Â  
A.  Sufficiency of Writings
Midland
  Parkway argues sufficient writings
  memorializing the alleged agreement exist.Â  We disagree.
Pursuant
  to the South Carolina Statute of Frauds, any contract for an interest in land
  must be in writing and signed by the party against whom enforcement is sought. S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 32-3-10(4) (2007).Â  A writing sufficient to remove an oral
  agreement from the Statute of Frauds â€œmust reasonably identify the subject matter
  of the contract, sufficiently indicate a contract has been made between the
  parties, and state with reasonable certainty the essential terms of the
  agreement.â€Â  Smith v. McClam, 289 S.C. 452, 456, 346 S.E.2d 720, 723
  (1986).Â  
In this case, no
  sufficient writing exists to satisfy the Statute of Frauds.Â  Midland contends
  the February 19 Letter from Lubelchek and the October 9, 2002 e-mail
  from Dresser together satisfy the writing requirement.Â  However, neither the
  letter nor the e-mail sufficiently describes the elements essential for a
  contract for the conveyance of land.Â  As previously discussed, the February 19
  letter does not contain the essential terms of an agreement.Â  The e-mail merely
  explains Irickâ€™s continued interest in the property and describes the status of
  the February 19 requirements. Â These writings, individually or read together,
  fail to satisfy the writing requirement of the Statute of Frauds. Â Â Accordingly,
  we find the trial judge did not err in granting summary judgment.
B.  Part Performance Exception
  to the Statute of Frauds 
Midland argues its part performance of the contract is
  sufficient to avoid the Statute of Frauds.Â  We find this issue not preserved
  for our review.Â  An issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal but must
  have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.Â  Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000).Â  In this case, the trial
  court did not rule on the part performance exception to the Statute of Frauds.Â 
  Accordingly, this issue is not preserved for our review. 
III.  Promissory
  Estoppel
Next, Midland argues the court erred in not finding Wilmington estopped from denying the contract.Â  We disagree.Â  
The elements of
  promissory estoppel are: â€œ(1) the presence of a promise unambiguous in its
  terms; (2) reasonable reliance upon the promise by the party to whom the
  promise is made; (3) the reliance is expected and foreseeable by the party who
  makes the promise; and (4) the party to whom the promise is made must sustain
  injury in reliance on the promise.â€Â  Rushing v. McKinney, 370 S.C. 280,
  295, 633 S.E.2d 917, 925 (Ct. App. 2006) (emphasis omitted).
Midland failed to
  show the existence of an unambiguous promise.Â  As discussed above, no evidence
  in the record indicates a meeting of the minds as to the alleged agreement. Â The
  letter indicating Wilmington would â€œconsiderâ€ conveying the wetland parcel is
  ambiguous, as explained to Irick by Midlandâ€™s counsel.Â  We find no error by the
  trial court in denying Midland recovery on its claim
  of promissory estoppel.
IV.  Fraudulent
  Misrepresentation 
Midland argues the
  trial court erred in finding insufficient evidence to maintain a claim for
  fraudulent misrepresentation.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe elements of
  an action for fraud based on a representation include:Â  1) a representation; 2)
  falsity; 3) its materiality; (4)
  knowledge of the falsity or a reckless disregard of its truth or falsity; (5)
  intent that the representation be acted upon; (6) the hearerâ€™s ignorance of its falsity; (7) the hearerâ€™s
  reliance upon its truth; (8) the hearerâ€™s right to rely thereon; and (9) the
  hearerâ€™s consequent and proximate injury.â€Â  Redwend Ltd. Partnership v.
    Edwards, 354 S.C. 459, 473, 581 S.E.2d 496, 503-04 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  All
  elements in an action for fraudulent misrepresentation must be met.Â  See Oâ€™Shields v. Southern Fountain Mobile Homes, Inc., 262 S.C. 276, 281,
  204 S.E.2d 50, 52 (1974) (finding lack of any one of the elements of fraudulent
  misrepresentation fatal to recovery).Â  
In this case, even
  if we assume all other elements are met, Midland fails to establish the element
  of the right to rely on the alleged misrepresentation.Â  Whether reliance is
  justified requires the court to review the attendant circumstances.Â  Elders
    v. Parker, 286 S.C. 228, 233, 332 S.E.2d 563, 567 (Ct. App. 1985). Â The
  general rule is that questions concerning reliance and its reasonableness are
  for the jury.Â  Unlimited Servs., Inc. v. Macklen Enters., 303 S.C. 384, 387,
  401 S.E.2d 153, 155 (1991).Â  However, the trial court may rule on the reasonableness
  of the reliance as a matter of law where the party asserting the
  misrepresentation fails to provide evidence of a factual dispute on the issue.Â  See Moorhead v. First Piedmont Bank & Trust Co., 273
  S.C. 356, 360, 256 S.E.2d 414, 416 (1979) (finding no jury issue on question of
  reasonableness of reliance).
We find the trial
  court did not err in finding Midlandâ€™s did not reasonably rely on a
  misrepresentation by Wilmington.Â  Even assuming Irick could reasonably rely on
  an oral representation by Libelcheck in a telephone conversation, the February
  19 Letter and Midlandâ€™s counselâ€™s advice rendered any further
  reliance on the alleged agreement unreasonable as a matter of law.Â  

  V.Â  South Carolina Unfair Trade
    Practices Act
Finally, Midland contends it is entitled to proceed on its claim under the UTPA.Â Â  We find Midland abandoned this issue.
An issue is deemed
  abandoned and will not be considered on appeal if the argument is raised in a
  brief but not supported by authority.Â  Glasscock, Inc. v. United States Fid. & Guar. Co., 348 S.C. 76, 81, 557 S.E.2d 689, 691 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  In
  the present case, Midland failed to cite any authority in support of its
  argument that it was entitled to proceed on its UTPA claim.Â  Accordingly, this
  court need not consider this issue on appeal.
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing
  reasons, we find the trial judge properly granted summary judgment on all of Midlandâ€™s causes of action.Â  Accordingly, the trial judgeâ€™s order is
AFFIRMED. 
ANDERSON, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.


[1]  We
  decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]  His brother, Lawton Irick, is the only other
  partner.Â  
[3]  Midland intended to build additional units on
  its existing property and the number of units it could construct depended on
  whether Wilmington would handle the drainage problem on its own property or
  whether Midland would be required to construct a retention pond, thereby
  decreasing the amount of land available for construction.

  2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Glenn B. Manning, of Dillon, for Appellant.
				A. LaFon LeGette, Jr., of Latta, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Luevenia
  S. Wright, as Personal Representative for the Estate of Yvonne Chyrelle K.
  McRae, has appealed in this matter involving foreclosure of a real estate
  mortgage on property formerly owned by Yvonne McRae.Â  We affirm.Â  
In his motion to the special referee to set aside the foreclosure
  and sale, Roger McRae, who was then Yvonne McRaeâ€™s surviving spouse and the
  Personal Representative of her estate, asserted in relevant part as follows:

	3.Â  That First Bank of Dillon brought the above action against
  Yvonne Chyrelle McRae (only later changed the caption of the case to reflect
  the Personal Representative of her estate as defendant, since she had died in
  May 2004.), which is a foreclosure on her property situated at the corner of
  Calhoun Street and Highway 57 South in Dillon.
	4.Â  That in August 2003, Yvonne C. McRae, had disputed, in a
  letter to the officials at First Bank, the validity of said mortgage . . . and
  she was in the process of filing suit against the Bank for release of said
  mortgage just before she died.
	5.Â  That Roger McRae, the Personal Representative for the Estate
  of Yvonne C. McRae, was hospitalized . . . on March 22, 2005, the date of the
  foreclosure hearing . . . and was not able to appear and present his defense
  against the claims of the Plaintiff, which resulted in the issuance of an order
  for sale by default judgment. 
	6. That Roger E. McRae, the Personal Representative for the Estate
  of Yvonne C. McRae, was not served a notice of sale of the property
  ordered foreclosed, as is required by South Carolina law; and no certification of service is filed in the Court of Common Pleas.Â  
	

The special referee denied the motion to set aside the foreclosure
  and sale on the basis it was untimely made.Â  Â Â 
In the Statement of Issues on Appeal, Wright now asserts the
  following four issues: Â (1) â€œthe appellant [i.e., Roger E. McRae, as the
  Personal Representative for the Estate of Yvonne Chyrelle K. McRae] and heirs
  at law were not enjoined as defendants pursuant to state law for the lower
  court to issue an order of foreclosure on real property under his jurisdictionâ€;
  (2) â€œthe Special Referee acted with prejudice in enjoining the appellant as
  defendant at a hearing of default and ordering a foreclosure saleâ€; (3) â€œthere
  was no transcript of record for the default hearing made, preserved, or filed
  in the office of the clerk of courtâ€; and (4) â€œthere was no certificate of
  service of the Order or Judgment from the default hearing and no notice
  of judgment from the lower court, and thus [this] prejudiced the subsequent
  rights of the appellant in the foreclosure proceedings.â€Â  
The only issues that were arguably raised below relate to the
  amendment of the pleadings and the service of the foreclosure order.Â  However,
  we find no error in the special refereeâ€™s determination that the motion to set
  aside was untimely made.Â  Moreover, as to the amendment of the pleadings to add
  the Personal Representative for the Estate of Yvonne Chyrelle K. McRae as a
  party, we note it is not necessary to make the personal representative of a
  deceased mortgagor a party to an action of foreclosure.Â  See S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 29-3-610 (2007) (â€œIt shall not be necessary to make the personal
  representative of a deceased mortgagor a party to any foreclosure proceeding
  and no sale heretofore made under foreclosure proceedings to which the personal
  representative of a deceased mortgagor was not a party shall be invalid by
  reason of the absence of such personal representative.â€).Â  
As to the lack of a transcript, this was never raised to and ruled
  upon by the special referee.Â  Accordingly, it is not preserved for our
  consideration.Â  See Pye v.
    Estate of Fox, 369 S.C. 555, 564, 633
  S.E.2d 505, 510 (2006) (â€œIt is well settled that an issue
  cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must
  have been raised to and ruled upon
  by the trial court to be preserved.â€); Wilder Corp. v.
    Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is
  axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised
  for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised
  to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€); Gurganious v. City of Beaufort, 317 S.C. 481, 488, 454 S.E.2d 912, 916 (Ct. App. 1995) (stating â€œa
  contemporaneous objection to a disputed ruling is required to preserve an issue
  for appellate reviewâ€).Â  Accordingly,
  the decision of the special referee is 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and
  KITTREDGE and THOMAS, JJ., concur.

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE

<!--

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				State of South Carolina,  Respondent,
				v.
				Jerene Markwell
      Hayward, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal from Richland County
James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge 
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-088
Submitted February 1, 2008 â€“ Filed
  February 8, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Aileen P. Clare, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General
  John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General 
				Salley W. Elliott; and Solicitor Warren B. Giese, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER
  CURIAM:Â  Jerene Markwell Hayward (Hayward) was convicted of first-degree
  burglary, the lesser-included offense of assault and battery of a high and
  aggravated nature (ABHAN), petit larceny, and possession of marijuana.Â  He was
  sentenced to consecutive terms of thirty (30) years for first-degree burglary
  and ten (10) years for ABHAN, plus concurrent terms of thirty (30) days each
  for the remaining convictions.Â  Hayward argues the trial court erred in: (1)
  admitting an impermissibly suggestive show-up identification; and (2) denying
  his motion for mistrial after a witness for the State commented on Haywardâ€™s exercise of his Fifth Amendment right to remain silent.Â  We affirm. [1]
FACTS
Hayward was accused of
  burglarizing the home of Jeffrey Connell and assaulting Connellâ€™s domestic
  employee on April 13, 2004.Â  On that same afternoon, Ronald Cowart, a
  landscaper, was in route to Crescent Lake Subdivision when Hayward ran out in
  front of Cowartâ€™s truck, exclaiming two people were in pursuit of him.Â  Cowart
  talked with Hayward and gave him a ride.Â  Cowart observed Hayward was a tall,
  slender black male, with close-cut hair and a mark or tattoo on his neck.Â  Hayward was wearing baggy blue jeans and a dark, long-sleeved shirt.Â  He was carrying a
  backpack.Â  Hayward eventually left Cowartâ€™s vehicle to find a store and a
  phone.Â  Cowart alerted the police in response to conduct he believed was â€œout
  of the ordinaryâ€ and the noticeable police activity in the area. 
Police arrested Hayward, informed him of his Miranda rights, and summoned Cowart several hours
  later to identify Hayward.Â  At the site of arrest Hayward was handcuffed and
  surrounded by police cars and uniformed officers.Â  Cowart positively identified
  Hayward as the man he had spoken with and picked up earlier.Â  He testified,
  â€œI said yes this is him, I know him.â€Â  
Eric Barnes, an
  investigator with Richland County Sheriffâ€™s Department, was responsible for
  directing the investigation.Â  As he arrived on the scene where Hayward was
  detained, he recalled Hayward was shouting that he was innocent.Â  Barnes
  introduced himself to Hayward and looked at Haywardâ€™s shoeprint to determine if
  it was similar to one left at the crime scene. Â Barnes observed what he thought
  was blood on Haywardâ€™s shoes, removed them, and secured them as evidence.
Barnes continued
  talking with Hayward, commenting that Hayward â€œwas going to have a hard time
  explaining how the victimâ€™s blood got on the shoe.â€Â  Hayward said â€œhe was in
  the house but it was the other guy that kicked her or hit the lady, not him.â€
At headquarters,
  Barnes verbally informed Hayward of his Miranda rights, asked Hayward if he understood, and attempted to obtain information from him.Â  Barnes testified Hayward denied he made the statement at the arrest site claiming he was not the one who
  kicked the lady.Â  Hayward continued to deny everything about the case at that
  point, becoming louder and louder as the discussion progressed.Â  When Barnes
  realized it was futile to continue, he decided to adjourn the session,
  concluding, â€œit became apparent in my mind that [Hayward] didnâ€™t want to give a
  statement.â€
Hayward was
  indicted for first-degree
  burglary, petit larceny, kidnapping, assault and battery with intent to kill,
  and possession of marijuana.
In a hearing
  pursuant to Jackson v. Denno, 378 U.S. 368, (1964), Hayward challenged
  the suggestiveness of Cowartâ€™s identification of him at the arrest site.Â  The
  trial court ruled Cowartâ€™s identification was admissible.
Additionally, Hayward moved for a mistrial on the ground Barnes impermissibly commented on Haywardâ€™s constitutional right to remain silent.Â  The trial court denied Haywardâ€™s motion
  and ruled Hayward had not invoked his right to remain silent at the time Barnes
  decided it was futile to continue the session.Â  Therefore, Barnesâ€™ comment that
  Haywardâ€™s statement was not forthcoming did not reflect on Haywardâ€™s
  invocation of his Fifth Amendment right.Â  
The jury found Hayward guilty of first-degree burglary, the
  lesser-included offense of ABHAN, petit larceny, and possession of marijuana.Â 
  The trial court sentenced Hayward to consecutive terms of thirty years (30) for
  first-degree burglary and ten (10) years for ABHAN, plus concurrent terms of
  thirty days (30) each for the remaining convictions.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In criminal cases,
  the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.Â  State v. Baccus,
  367 S.C. 41, 48, 625 S.E.2d 216, 220 (2006).Â  Thus, an appellate court is bound
  by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  Id. at 48, 625 S.E.2d at 220. Â This same standard of review applies to preliminary
  factual findings in determining the admissibility of certain evidence in
  criminal cases.Â  State v. Preslar, 364 S.C. 466, 472, 613 S.E.2d 381,
  384 (Ct. App. 2005).
DISCUSSION
I.  Admissibility
  of Show-Up IdentificationÂ  
Hayward contends
  Cowartâ€™s identification of him at the arrest site should be suppressed because
  it was so suggestive that Cowartâ€™s objectivity was compromised. Â We disagree. 
Generally, the
  decision to admit an eyewitness identification is at the trial courtâ€™s
  discretion and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion,
  or the commission of prejudicial legal error.Â  State v. Moore, 343 S.C.
  282, 288, 540 S.E.2d 445, 448 (2000); State v. McCord, 349 S.C. 477,
  481, 562 S.E.2d 689, 691 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  However, an eyewitness
  identification which is unreliable because of suggestive police procedures is
  constitutionally inadmissible as a matter of law.Â  Moore, 343 S.C. at
  288, 540 S.E.2d at 448.Â  
A criminal
  defendant may be deprived of due process of law by an unnecessarily suggestive
  identification procedure conducive to irreparable mistaken identification.Â  State
    v. Roach, 364 S.C. 422, 429-30, 613 S.E.2d 791, 795 (2005); State v.
      Brown, 356 S.C. 496, 503, 589 S.E.2d 781, 785 (Ct. App. 2003); State v.
        Mansfield, 343 S.C. 66, 79, 538 S.E.2d 257, 264 (Ct. App. 2000); State
          v. Blassingame, 338 S.C. 240, 251, 525 S.E.2d 535, 541 (Ct. App. 1999).
The
  United States Supreme Court and the South Carolina Supreme Court have
  established a two-prong inquiry to determine the admissibility of an
  out-of-court identification.Â  Neil v. Biggers, 409 U.S. 188, 196 (1972); Moore, 343 S.C. at 287, 540 S.E.2d at 448.Â  A court must determine
  whether the identification process was unduly suggestive.Â  Moore, 343
  S.C. at 287, 540 S.E.2d at 448.Â  Only if the identification procedure was
  unduly suggestive does the court need to consider the next step, whether the
  out-of-court identification was nevertheless so reliable that no substantial
  likelihood of misidentification existed.Â  Id.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Single
  person show-ups have been sharply criticized as unnecessarily suggestive. Â Mansfield , 343 S.C. at 79, 538 S.E.2d at 264.Â  However, suggestiveness alone does
  not require the exclusion of evidence.Â  State v Stewart, 275 S.C. 447,
  450, 272 S.E.2d 628, 629 (1980). Â The central question is whether, under the
  totality of the circumstances, the identification was reliable even though the
  confrontation procedure was suggestive. Id.; Mansfield, 343 S.C.
  at 79, 538 S.E.2d at 264.Â  Reliability is the â€œlinchpin in determining the
  admissibility of identification testimony.â€Â  Mansfield, 343 S.C. at 79,
  538 S.E.2d at 264.Â  To determine whether identification is reliable, we must
  consider the factors set forth in Biggers.Â  409 U.S. at 199.Â  The factors to be considered are: 

	1) the
  opportunity of the witness to view the criminal at the time of the crime; 2)
  the witnessâ€™s degree of attention; 3) the accuracy of the witnessâ€™s prior
  description of the criminal; 4) the level of certainty demonstrated by the
  witness at the confrontation; and 5) the amount of time between the crime and
  the confrontation.

Biggers, 409 U.S. at 200; Mansfield, 343 S.C. at 79,
  538 S.E.2d at 264. 
At the arrest site,
  Hayward was presented in handcuffs, surrounded by police cars and uniformed
  officers.Â  Notwithstanding the somewhat suggestive nature of the setting, Cowartâ€™s
  identification of Hayward was reliable in light of the totality of the
  circumstances.Â  
Cowart had opportunity
  to observe Hayward in close proximity, during daylight hours, on the day the
  crimes were committed.Â  Cowartâ€™s attention was focused on Hayward because of
  his unusual behavior.Â  He was suspicious of Hayward to the point he removed his
  keys and cell phone from Haywardâ€™s view, and he ultimately alerted the police
  about his contact with Hayward.
Cowart described Hayward in accurate detail to the police as a tall, slender black male with close cut hair.Â 
  He noted Haywardâ€™s clothing, observed the backpack he carried, and identified a
  green cigarette package that Hayward pulled out of the bag.Â  Cowart
  unequivocally and without hesitation confirmed Hayward was the man he picked up
  in the victimâ€™s neighborhood on the afternoon of April 13, 2004.Â  Moreover, the
  amount of time between Cowartâ€™s afternoon encounter with Hayward and the
  show-up identification at the arrest site was approximately three hours.Â  

	The
  trial court concluded:
	Case law
  indicates that even if the identification is unnecessarily suggestive the
  evidence need not be excluded if the totality of the circumstances indicates
  that the identification is reliable.Â  And I find that there is sufficient
  evidence that has been shown to this court that the identification is reliable.

In reviewing
  Cowartâ€™s identification for indicia of reliability, the trial court considered
  the factors required under Biggers.Â  The trial court did not abuse its
  discretion when it denied Haywardâ€™s motion to suppress Cowartâ€™s identification.
II.  Failure to Grant Motion
  for Mistrial
Hayward contends the
  trial court erred in denying his motion for a mistrial when Barnes allegedly commented
  on Haywardâ€™s exercise of his Fifth Amendment right to remain silent.Â  We
  disagree.
The decision to grant or deny a mistrial is within the
  sound discretion of the trial court.Â  State v. Stanley, 365 S.C. 24, 33,
  615 S.E.2d 455, 460 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  The trial courtâ€™s decision will not be
  overturned on appeal absent an abuse of discretion amounting to an error of
  law.Â  Id.; State v. Rowlands, 343 S.C. 454, 458, 539 S.E.2d 717,
  719 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  A mistrial should only be granted when â€œabsolutely
  necessary,â€ and a defendant must show both error and resulting prejudice in
  order to be entitled to a mistrial.Â  Stanley, 365 S.C. at 34, 615 S.E.2d
  at 460.Â  Whether a mistrial is manifestly necessary is a fact specific
  inquiry.Â  Id.Â Â Â Â Â  
Hayward asserts Barnesâ€™ comment, â€œit became apparent in my
  mind that [Hayward] didnâ€™t want to give a statement,â€ was an impermissible
  reference to Haywardâ€™s right to remain silent under Doyle v. Ohio, 426 U.S. 610 (1976).Â  In Doyle, the
  Supreme Court held: 

	â€˜[W]hen a person is informed, as Miranda requires, that he
  may remain silent, that anything he says may be used against him, â€¦ it does not
  comport with due process to permit the prosecution during the trial to call
  attention to his silence at the time of arrest and to insist that because he
  did not speak about the facts of the case at that time, as he was told he need
  not do, an unfavorable inference might be drawn as to the truth of his trial
  testimony.â€™Â  

Id. at 619 (quoting U.S. v. Hale, 422 U.S. 171, 182-83 (1975)).
The courts of South Carolina have
  consistently recognized the significance of Doyle on post-arrest, post-Miranda silence.Â  â€œDoyle holds that the Due Process Clause prohibits the
  government from commenting on an accusedâ€™s post-Miranda silence.â€Â  State
    v. Simmons, 360 S.C. 33, 39, 599 S.E.2d 448, 450 (2004); Payne v. State,
  355 S.C. 642, 645, 586 S.E.2d 857, 859 (2003) (holding â€œThe state may not
  directly or indirectly comment on the defendantâ€™s right to remain silent.â€).Â  Our appellate courts have warned solicitors against violation of
  the Doyle prohibition.Â  State v. Myers, 301 S.C. 251, 258-259,
  391 S.E.2d 551, 555 (1990); State v. Arther, 290 S.C. 291, 350 S.E.2d
  187 (1990); State v. Holliday, 333 S.C. 332, 509 S.E.2d 280 (Ct. App.
  1998); State v. Gray, 304 S.C. 482, 405 S.E.2d 420 (Ct. App. 1991). However, â€œ[t]he underpinnings of Doyle,
  and the need for its application, are diminished where a defendant waives his
  right to silence.Â  Simmons, 360 S.C. at 40, 599 S.E.2d at 451.
In the
  instant case the trial court concluded the State made a sufficient showing that
  Hayward was advised of his rights under Miranda.Â  The trial court
  found after being advised of those rights, Hayward essentially waived them by
  voluntarily making statements and utterances.Â  â€œI find based on what has been
  presented that the defendant had not at that point and [sic] time invoked his
  right to remain silent.Â  For that reason I will permit the testimony to
  continue.Â  I deny the motion for a mistrial.â€
Police
  informed Hayward of his Miranda rights at the arrest site.Â 
  Nevertheless, Hayward continued to shout about his innocence and professed the
  acts were committed by other perpetrators.Â  After hearing his Miranda rights again during the discussion with Barnes at headquarters, Hayward persisted in talking about his innocence, disclaiming things he had allegedly said
  earlier.Â  In the context of ending the session because of its futility, Barnesâ€™
  comment was not in response to Haywardâ€™s silence, because Hayward was not
  silent, and had not yet invoked his right to remain silent.Â  The trial court did
  not err in denying Haywardâ€™s motion for mistrial.Â  
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, SHORT, and THOMAS, JJ., concur.


[1]  We decide this case without oral argument
  pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

Submitted February 1, 2008 â€“ Filed

FACTS
This

  which Jennifer Christmas was a passenger was struck from behind by a vehicle
  driven by Dale Eugene Enos, Jr.Â  Jennifer and her husband Jay Christmas brought
  this action against Enos and his employer A Rainbow of Carpets, Inc., alleging
  causes of action for negligence, negligent entrustment, negligent hiring,
  supervision, and training, and loss of consortium.Â   
On
  November 30, 2005, the jury returned a general verdict in favor of Jennifer
  Christmas in the amount of $30,000.Â  It awarded no damages to Jay Christmas.Â 
  Appellants filed a motion for a new trial on December 12, 2005.Â  The trial
  court denied this motion in an order filed December 22, 2005.Â  Appellants
  received this order on December 29, 2005 and on January 8, 2006, filed a motion
  to reconsider or to alter or amend judgment pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP.Â  The
  trial court denied this motion February 22, 2006 in a form order.Â  Appellants
  received written notice of the entry of this order on February 28, 2006.Â  They
  served their notice of appeal on March 29, 2006.Â   
LAW/ANALYSIS
â€œThe requirement of service of the notice of appeal is
  jurisdictional, i.e., if a party misses the deadline, the appellate
  court lacks jurisdiction to consider the appeal and has no authority or
  discretion to â€˜rescueâ€™ the delinquent party by extending or ignoring the deadline
  for service of the notice.â€ Â Elam v. South Carolina Department of
    Transportation, 361 S.C. 9, 14-15, 602 S.E.2d 772, 775 (2004).Â  An
  appellant must serve the notice of appeal in a case appealed from the Court of
  Common Pleas on all respondents within thirty days after receipt of written
  notice of entry of the order or judgment.Â  Rule 203(b)(1), SCACR.Â  A timely
  post-trial motion, including a motion to alter or amend the judgment pursuant
  to Rule 59(e), SCRCP, stays the time for an appeal for all parties until
  receipt of written notice of entry of the order granting or denying such
  motion.Â  Elam, 361 S.C. at 15, 602 S.E.2d at 775.Â  However, a successive
  post-trial motion, where a party simply recaptions a written motion for
  judgment notwithstanding the verdict (JNOV) or new trial, which has been ruled
  on, and resubmits it as a virtually identical, written Rule 59(e) motion does
  not stay the time for the service of the notice of appeal.Â  Quality Trailer
    Products v. CSL Equipment Co., 349 S.C. 216, 220, 562 S.E.2d 615, 618
  (2002).Appellantsâ€™ motion to alter or amend is virtually identical to their
  motion for a new trial other than the caption and opening paragraphs setting
  forth the procedural history.Â  In the motion to alter or amend, Appellants did
  not request the trial court rule on an issue raised in the prior motion and not
  ruled on nor did they challenge a new ruling.Â  Thus, as in Quality Trailer
    Products, this successive motion did not stay the time for serving the
  notice of appeal.Â  Appellants received the trial courtâ€™s order denying their
  written motion for new trial on December 29, 2005.Â  They had thirty days from
  this date in which to serve their notice of Appeal on the Christmases.Â 
  Appellants, however, did not serve the notice of appeal until March 29, 2006.Â 
  As the service of the notice of appeal was untimely, this court lacks
  jurisdiction to consider the appeal.Â   
Accordingly, the appeal is  
DISMISSED.
HUFF AND PIEPER, JJ., and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR
  RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2),
  SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Joseph Thomas, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Alexander S. Macaulay, Circuit Court
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-114
Submitted February 1, 2008 â€“ Filed
  February 13, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant
  Attorney General Shawn L. Reeves, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Harold W.
  Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â 
  Joseph Thomas seeks to vacate a conviction and sentence, arguing the trial
  courtâ€™s denial of his motion for a continuance rendered his guilty plea
  invalid.Â  In the alternative, Thomas seeks a new trial.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
In 2004, the Spartanburg County Grand Jury
  indicted Thomas on one count of trafficking in more than 200 grams of cocaine, one
  count of possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime, and
  one count of trafficking in more than ten grams of crack cocaine.Â  In addition,
  Thomas was also facing a federal charge for conspiracy to escape.  
On July 5, 2005, the assistant United States attorney moved to dismiss the federal charge, purportedly so that Thomas could be
  extradited to the Bahamas, where he had been charged with murder of a police
  officer.Â  Although the details are not clear, there was allegedly an agreement
  that, if the federal charges were dismissed, the State would likewise dismiss
  the state charges, thus facilitating the extradition.  
At the request of the State, the attorney representing Thomas on
  the state charges was relieved in February 2006 and a public defender was
  appointed to represent him soon after.Â  The public defender first met with
  Thomas on June 5, 2006, when he allegedly learned Thomasâ€™s trial on the state
  charges was scheduled for the following week.Â  About that time, defense counsel
  also received information about the alleged agreement under which the state
  charges would be dismissed.Â   
The case was called for trial on June 12, 2006.Â  When the hearing
  began, defense counsel moved for a continuance in the matter, requesting more
  time to investigate whether the state charges against Thomas should have been
  dismissed as a result of the charges pending against him in the Bahamas.Â  The trial court denied the request, noting the case had been on the docket since
  March 2006.Â  In addition, the court found Thomas would suffer no legal
  prejudice from the denial of the continuance because the disposition of the
  other charges pending against Thomas would not affect the state charges.Â  
 
Following a short recess after the denial of the continuance,
  Thomas agreed to plead guilty to the charge of trafficking in more than 200
  grams of cocaine.Â  In addition, the State agreed to dismiss the firearm charge
  and the indictment for trafficking in crack cocaine.Â  The trial court accepted
  Thomasâ€™s guilty plea and sentenced him to twenty-five years confinement.Â  This
  appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œA motion for a
  continuance is addressed to the sound discretion of the trial court and its
  ruling on such motion will not be reversed without a clear showing of abuse of
  discretion.â€Â  State v. Tanner, 299 S.C. 459, 462, 385 S.E.2d 832, 834
  (1989).Â  â€œWhere there is no showing that any other evidence on behalf of
  the appellant could have been produced, or that any other points could have
  been raised had more time been granted for the purpose of preparing the case
    for trial, the denial of a motion for continuance is not an abuse of
  discretion.â€Â  State v. Williams, 321 S.C. 455, 459, 469 S.E.2d 49, 51-52
  (1996) (emphasis added).Â  A guilty plea acts as a waiver of all
  non-jurisdictional defects and defenses.Â  State v. McKennedy, 348 S.C.
  270, 280, 559 S.E.2d 850, 855 (2002).
LAW/ANALYSIS
We agree with the
  State that Thomasâ€™s guilty plea amounted to a waiver of his argument that he
  should have received a continuance.Â  See Whetsell v. State, 276
  S.C. 295, 299, 277 S.E.2d 891, 892 (1981) (â€œThe general rule is that guilty
  pleas, freely and voluntarily entered, act as a waiver of all
  non-jurisdictional defects and defenses, including the claims of a violation of
  a constitutional right prior to the plea.â€).Â   
Furthermore,
  defense counselâ€™s reason for requesting a continuance was to verify his
  understanding that it was because of the pending state charges that federal
  authorities had not taken Thomas into custody.Â  In response to the motion, the
  solicitor advised the court that (1) a conviction and sentence on the state
  charges would not prevent extradition; (2) the Bahamian government had not yet
  begun the formal extradition process; and (3) such a process would take several
  years.Â  Moreover, as the solicitor noted, Thomasâ€™s defense counsel had been
  assigned to the case more than three months before the scheduled trial and the
  State had incurred considerable expenses to secure the presence of certain
  witnesses.Â  Under these circumstances, we hold defense counsel failed to make
  any showing that a continuance would have enabled him to prepare more fully for
  trial and the trial court therefore acted within its discretion in denying the
  continuance.
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, SHORT, and THOMAS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.

PER CURIAM:Â  Janet
  Miller brought suit against FerrellGas L.P., Inc. and Kenneth W. Ellis

  The trial court granted Miller a directed verdict on the issue of negligence,
  and the jury awarded her $785,000 in damages.Â  FerrellGas appeals.Â  We reverse

FACTS
On June 15, 2001, Ronald Owens was driving Miller to Hilton Head Island to have an MRI for an injury she had sustained in a work-related
  accident six days earlier when they were involved in an accident with a truck
  driven by Kenneth Ellis, an employee of FerrellGas.Â  While traveling on Highway
  170, Owens and Miller approached a caution light at the intersection of
  Highways 802 and 170 where the truck driven by Ellis was stopped at a stop
  sign.Â  Ellis testified he stopped at the stop sign and looked both ways.Â  A
  road construction sign, which had not been there earlier in the day, obstructed
  his view to the left.Â  Ellis looked to the right again and then eased out to
  look around the sign.Â  When he did not see anything, he pulled out into the intersection
  where his truck collided with the automobile in which Miller rode.Â  Ellis defended the actions he took on the day of the
  accident and testified he was not the cause of the traffic accident.Â   
Miller brought the present action seeking damages for the injuries
  she allegedly sustained in the accident.Â  At the close of FerrellGasâ€™s case,
  the trial court granted Millerâ€™s motion for directed verdict on the issue of
  negligence.Â  Furthermore, the court noted the difficulty a motorist would face
  in this situation and stated, â€œI donâ€™t know what youâ€™re supposed to do.Â  Are
  you supposed to get out of the car and go to the front and check?Â  Thatâ€™s the
  dilemma here.â€Â  After deliberations, the jury awarded Miller $785,000 in
  damages.Â  The trial court denied FerrellGasâ€™s post-trial motion.Â  This appeal
  followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
FerrellGas argues
  the trial court erred in granting Miller a directed verdict motion on the issue
  of negligence.Â  We agree.Â   
When
  reviewing the grant of a directed verdict, this court must view the evidence
  and all reasonable inferences therefrom in the light most favorable to the
  party against whom the verdict was directed.Â  Heyward v. Christmas, 357
  S.C. 202, 207, 593 S.E.2d 141, 144 (2004). Â If the evidence is susceptible to
  more than one reasonable inference, the case should have been submitted to the
  jury.Â  Id.Â  The court is not concerned with the weight of the evidence,
  but whether there is any evidence from which the jury is warranted in making a
  finding.Â  Washington v. Whitaker, 317 S.C. 108, 113-14, 451
  S.E.2d 894, 897-98 (1994).Â  Furthermore, neither the trial court nor the
  appellate court has authority to decide credibility issues or to resolve
  conflicts in the testimony or evidence.Â  Erickson v. Jones St. Publishers,
    LLC, 368 S.C. 444, 463, 629 S.E.2d 653, 663 (2006).Â  â€œThe appellate court
  must determine whether a verdict for a party opposing the motion would be
  reasonably possible under the facts as liberally construed in his favor.â€Â  Id.Â  
 
In
  the present case, there is no evidence indicating Miller, as a passenger in the
  traffic accident, was negligent.Â  Therefore, the issue before us is whether the
  record contains any evidence showing Ellis was not negligent.Â   
Ellis
  was required by law to stop at the intersection of Highways 802 and 107.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2330(b) (2006) (requiring drivers to stop at stop signs
  with a view of approaching traffic before entering the intersecting roadway).Â 
  After coming to a stop, Ellis was then required to â€œyield to the right-of-way to
  any vehicle in the intersection or approaching on another roadway so closely as
  to constitute an immediate hazard during the time when such driver is moving
  across or within the intersection or junction of roadways.â€Â  Id.Â  
 
The
  South Carolina Supreme Court has previously addressed the duty of a driver
  crossing over a highway, such as presented in this case, by explaining:  

	When a
  motorist on an unfavored highway approaches a through highway he must bring his
  car to a stop for such a time and in such a position as to be able to observe
  the traffic conditions on the favored highway and govern his conduct
  accordingly.Â  The duty to yield the right of way does not mean that the driver
  on the unfavored highway must refrain from crossing the favored highway whenever
  another vehicle is approaching thereon regardless of how far distant.Â  
	

Warren v. Watkins Motor Lines, 242 S.C. 331, 340, 130 S.E.2d 896, 901 (1963).Â  
 
The
  court explained that travelers on both the favored and the unfavored highways
  have a duty to use ordinary care in keeping a proper lookout for vehicles
  approaching the intersection.Â  Id. Â at 341, 130 S.E.2d at 901.Â  The court held,
  â€œIf there is a conflict in the testimony as to whether a car on the through
  highway was approaching so closely as to constitute an immediate hazard or if
  the conclusion to be drawn therefrom is doubtful and uncertain, the Court will
  not decide the question as one of law and it must be submitted to the triers of
  the fact.â€Â  Id. Â at 341, 130 S.E.2d at 901-02.Â   
In Cope v.
  Eckert this court reiterated the duties set forth in Warren when a
  driver is crossing or turning over a favored roadway.Â  284 S.C. 516, 327 S.E.2d
  367 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  This court explained, â€œ[I]f there is no traffic
  approaching so near as to constitute an immediate hazard, the driver on the
  unfavored highway has a right to enter the intersection, and it then becomes
  the duty of those approaching the intersection on the favored highway to yield
  the right of way to him.â€Â  Id.Â  519, 327 S.E.2d at 369.
In the present case, Owens testified that as he approached the
  caution light of the intersection, he was traveling between forty and
  forty-five miles an hour.Â  He saw Ellisâ€™s truck stopped at the stop sign.Â  He
  claimed that when Ellis pulled out in front of his vehicle, he was about fifty
  to seventy-five yards away and had â€œno time to react.â€ Â 
Ellis testified he was familiar with this intersection and had
  driven through it earlier that day.Â  However, the scene at the intersection had
  changed when he approached for a second time because a construction sign was
  blocking his view.Â  He claimed that even
  with the construction sign obstructing his view, he took precautions to ensure
  the road was clear when he pulled into the intersection.Â  He stated he came to
  a full stop when he approached the intersection and looked to his left and his
  right.Â  Then he eased out to look around the sign and did not see anything
  coming, so he pulled into the intersection.Â   
Under
  the precedent of Warren and Cope, we find a jury issue was
  created based on the facts of this case.Â  Specifically, we believe the record
  contains some evidence from which a jury could infer Ellis was not negligent,
  thus creating more than one inference with regards to negligence.Â  A jury could
  reasonably infer Ellis proceeded into the intersection with enough caution and
  without perceiving Owenâ€™s vehicle as an immediate threat.Â  Though we note the
  great amount of evidence against FerrellGas, it is not our duty to weigh
  evidence but to look for any evidence in the trial record from which a jury
  could make more than one inference.Â  Because a jury could have inferred Ellis
  was not negligent, the trial court improperly directed a verdict against
  FerrellGas on the issue of negligence.Â  Accordingly, we reverse the trial
  courtâ€™s grant of a directed verdict and remand this case for a new trial.Â 
 
REVERSED
  AND REMANDED.[1]
HUFF
  and PIEPER, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.Â  

[1]Â  As we have remanded for a new trial, we need not
  address FerrellGasâ€™s remaining issues.Â  See Murphy v. Jefferson Pilot Communications Co., 364 S.C. 453, 465 n.3, 613 S.E.2d 808, 814 n.3 (Ct.
  App. 2005) (declining to address evidentiary issue in action remanded for new
  trial).
