title: GuideOne Insurance v. Evans
text:
THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Ex Parte:
      GuideOne Insurance Company, Carrier, Appellant,
				In 
				Re: 
				John T. Evans, Respondent,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				White Oaks Conference Center, Employer, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Fairfield County
Â Kenneth G. Goode, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2008-UP-122
Submitted January 2, 2008 â€“Filed February
  19, 2008
REVERSED IN PART, AFFIRMED IN PART AND REMANDED 


	
		
			
				Matthew R. Cook, of Columbia, for Appellants.
				J. Marvin Mullis, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Employer, White Oak Conference Center (Employer),[1] contends the circuit court erred in reversing the decision of the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission finding Claimant, John Evans (Evans), (1)
  had not suffered compensable injuries to his left knee and foot as a result of
  an on the job fall, and (2) had reached maximum medical improvement.Â  We
  reverse in part, affirm in part, and remand.[2]  
FACTS
On January 9, 2004, while working for
  Employer, Evans fell 15 feet from a ladder to the concrete floor below.Â  Evans
  landed directly on his feet.Â  An accident report, filled out at the scene of
  the accident, indicates injury to Evansâ€™ ankle.[3]Â 
  Later that day, after finishing work, Evans went to the Fairfield Memorial Hospital complaining of problems with his right ankle and foot.Â  He did not complain
  of any left ankle or knee pain.Â  Evans was diagnosed with a sprain of the right
  ankle and referred to Dr. Steven Barnett. Â Â 
Evans
  reported to Dr. Barnett, three days after the fall, complaining of a tremendous
  pain and swelling around the right ankle and foot.Â  Evans denied any other
  trauma or injury.Â  Dr. Barnett indicated Evans was â€œnot progressing as quickly
  as I had hoped,â€ and referred Evans to an orthopaedist, Dr. Bradley Presnal of
  the Moore Orthopaedic Clinic.Â  Dr. Presnal diagnosed a right ankle sprain. Â Because
  Evans continued to complain of right ankle pain even after a lengthy recovery period,
  Dr. Presnal referred Evans to Dr. Frank Noojin to rule out the need for
  arthroscopy. Â Â 
On
  August 31, 2004, Evans saw Dr. Green Neal via a referral from Evans lawyer.Â  Evans
  complained to Dr. Neal of left and right ankle pain and left knee pain.Â  Dr.
  Neal found â€œan enlarged right ankle . . . crepitation in the knees . . . [and
  that] the left ankle does not have that much crepitation but [Evans] complains
  of pain in it.â€Â  Dr. Neal diagnosed Evans with Type II diabetes suggesting it â€œis
  the reason [Evans] injuries would not heal.â€Â  Evans was also diagnosed with pre-existing
  gouty arthritis with elevated uric acid levels which Dr. Neal believed complicated
  Evans injuries and resulted in slowed recovery and failure to heal.Â  He also
  found these conditions were aggravated or worsened by the trauma from the
  fall.Â  Dr. Neal scheduled additional MRIâ€™s of Evansâ€™ left knee and ankle for
  September 14, 2004. Â Â 
Meanwhile, on September 2, 2004, Evans returned to Dr. Noojin, but
  did not complain of any injury or pain to his left ankle or knee.Â  Dr. Noojin found
  Evans at maximum medical improvement (MMI) and assigned a 3% permanent partial
  impairment rating to his right lower extremity.Â   
Evans
  returned to Dr. Neal on September 28, 2004.Â  Dr. Neal found: Evansâ€™ left ankle
  showed a contusion with a small amount of fluid, possibly associated with
  plantar fasciitis; Evansâ€™ left knee showed a thinning of the ACL suggesting
  degenerative changes; and Evansâ€™ right ankle evidenced a contusion and tear.Â 
  Finally, on November 3, 2004, Evans returned to Dr. Noojin complaining, for the
  first time, of bilateral ankle pain.Â  Yet, Evans did not bring the new MRIâ€™s
  nor mention to Dr. Noojin the findings of Dr. Neal.Â  Dr. Noojin reiterated his
  previous findings and discharged Evans at MMI. Â Â 
After an evidentiary hearing, the single commissioner
  issued an order finding Evans had reached MMI, awarding six percent permanent
  partial disability for the lower right extremity, and denying compensability
  for the injuries to the left foot and knee.Â  The single commissioner explained,
  â€œI give more weight to the reports of the authorized treating physicians than I
  do the testimony of [Evansâ€™] physician, who is not a certified orthopedist.â€Â 
  The order was affirmed by the full commission.Â  Evans then appealed to the
  circuit court.Â   
After a hearing, the circuit court found â€œ[t]he substantial
  evidence in the record is susceptible of but one reasonable inference,
  i.e. that the injuries to [Evansâ€™] left lower extremity were compensable as
  having been sustained along with the injuries to his right lower extremity in
  the admitted work accident.â€Â  (emphasis in original)Â  Further, the circuit court
  noted no evidence was presented to contradict the â€œexpert medical opinion of
  Dr. Neal indicating [Evansâ€™] left sided injuries were caused or at the
  very least aggravated by the work fall and injuries.â€ Â Thus, the circuit court reversed
  the denial of compensability for Evansâ€™ left-sided injuries, reversed the order
  of permanent partial disability, and remanded to the full commission for an
  order of causally related medical care. Â This appeal follows.Â   
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Appellate review of
  workersâ€™ compensation decisions is governed by the South Carolina Administrative
  Procedures Act (APA).Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 454, 535
  S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000); See also Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C.
  130, 134-35, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  Pursuant to the APA, a reviewing
  court may affirm the decision of an agency or remand the case for further
  proceedings, or may reverse or modify the decision of an agency if the
  findings, inferences, conclusions or decisions of that agency are â€œclearly
  erroneous in view of the reliable probative and substantial evidence on the
  whole record.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§1-23-380(A)(6) (2005); see also Bass
    v. Kenco Group, 366 S.C. 450, 456, 622 S.E.2d 577, 580 (Ct. App. 2005).Â Â Â  
 
The
  commission is the ultimate fact finder and is specifically reserved the task of
  assessing the credibility of the witnesses and the weight to be accorded
  evidence.Â  Shealy, 341 S.C. at 455, 535 S.E.2d at 442.Â  On appeal, this court
  determines whether the circuit court properly determined whether the commissionâ€™s
  findings of fact are supported by substantial evidence in the record or whether
  the commissionâ€™s decision is affected by an error of law.Â  Geathers v. 3V.
    Inc., 371 S.C. 570, 576, 641 S.E.2d 29, 32 (2007).Â  Substantial evidence is
  not a mere scintilla of evidence but rather is evidence which, considering the
  record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion that
  the commission reached.Â  Shealy, 341 S.C. at 455, 535 S.E.2d at 442; Rodney
    v. Michelin Tire Corp., 320 S.C. 515, 519, 466 S.E.2d 357, 359 (1996).Â  The
  mere possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does
  not prevent the commissionâ€™s findings from being supported by substantial
  evidence.Â  Grant v. S.C. Coastal Council, 319 S.C. 348, 353, 461 S.E.2d
  388, 391 (1995).Â Â  Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Employer contends
  the circuit court erred in reversing the decision of the commission because
  substantial evidence existed to support the decision in full.Â  We reverse and
  remand.Â   
Employer contends
  the circuit erred in reversing the commissionâ€™s finding and conclusion that
  Evans had not suffered compensable injuries to his left knee and foot as a
  result of the fall.Â   
On
  appeal, the circuit court found the commissionâ€™s decision was disproportionally
  based on the fact the accident and emergency room reports did not mention left
  sided symptoms and on the lack of evidence as to the left-sided injuries in the
  reports of the authorized physicians.Â  The circuit court found no expert
  medical evidence was offered to dispute Dr. Nealâ€™s testimony the left-sided
  injuries â€œwere caused or at the very least aggravated by the work fall
  and injuries.â€Â  The circuit court concluded,  

	the
  record is susceptible of but one reasonable inference, i.e. that the
  injuries to [Evans] left lower extremity were compensable . . . the
  Commissionâ€™s decision is unsupported where weight was given only to the opinion
  of the authorized treating physicians yet those physicians made no mention of
  [Evans] pre-existing conditions and left no opinion as to the effect of the
  fall on those conditions or the effect of those conditions on the injuries
  sustained in the fall.

We
  find the commission considered all the medical evidence and other testimony in
  finding Evans suffered no direct impairment of his lower left extremity or to
  his feet as a result of the accident.Â  The commission considered not only the
  accident report and hospital report from the day of the accident but also the
  reports of the authorized physicians and Dr. Neal.Â  However, the commission
  made no specific finding of fact concerning the issue of pre-existing
  conditions and possible aggravation presented by Evans.Â  â€œUnder the Workersâ€™
  Compensation Act, an injured claimant is entitled to compensation and medical
  benefits for disability arising from a permanent physical impairment in
  combination with a pre-existing impairment if the combined effect results in a
  substantially greater disability.â€Â  Curiel v. Envtl. Mgmt. Servs., Op.
  No. 26409 (S.C. Filed Dec. 20, 2007) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 43 at 40) (citing Ellison
    v. Frigidaire Home Prods., 371 S.C. 159, 638 S.E.2d 664 (2006) (applying
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-400 (1985 & Supp. 2005))).Â   
The
  commission must make specific findings of fact upon which a claimantâ€™s right to
  compensation is based.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§1-23-350 (2005); Shealy
    v. Algernon Blair, Inc., 250 S.C. 106, 109, 156 S.E.2d 646, 648 (1967); 73A
  C.J.S. Public Administrative Law and Procedure Â§274 (2007) (â€œWhere the
  requirements as to administrative findings are contained in statutes, the
  findings must comply therewith.â€)Â  An appellate court, reviewing an order of
  the commission, â€œcannot make findings of fact when the commission has failed to
  do so because, in doing so, [the] court would improperly assume the commissionâ€™s
  role as factfinder.â€Â  Nettles v. Spartanburg Sch. Dist. #7, 341 S.C.
  580, 590, 535 S.E.2d 146, 151 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  â€œIn reviewing a final decision of
  an ALJ, as when reviewing a final decision of an agency, the circuit court
  essentially sits as an appellate court to review alleged errors committed by
  the ALJ.â€Â  Al-Shabazz v. State, 338 S.C. 354, 379, 527 S.E.2d 742, 755
  (S.C. 2000). Â Because the commission did not make specific findings of fact concerning
  the issue of aggravation, we cannot conduct a meaningful review and must reverse
  the circuit courtâ€™s finding of an aggravated compensable left-sided injury and remand
  the issue to the commission.Â  See, e.g., Parsons v. Georgetown Steel,
  318 S.C. 63, 456 S.E.2d 366 (1995) (holding an order of the commission that
  does not include sufficiently detailed findings of fact must be remanded to the
  commission) Â Â Â 
Additionally,
  Employer contends the circuit court erred
  in reversing the commissionâ€™s finding and conclusion that Evans reached MMI.Â  We
  affirm.
The
  circuit court held the commissionâ€™s decision to decide the issue of permanent
  partial disability constituted a denial of due process.Â  The circuit court
  found Evans specified in his Form 50 that he was â€œnot requesting a permanency
  determination at this time.â€ Â The circuit court concluded Evans was entitled to
  notice of issues to be decided and was entitled to have the commission
  determine only those issues properly brought before it.Â  Â Â 
On
  appeal to this court, Employer asserts temporary benefits may be terminated
  upon a showing of MMI, citing Smith v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Mental Health, 335
  S.C. 396, 517 S.E.2d 694 (1999) and Anderson v. Baptist Medical Center and
    Palmetto Hospital Trust Fund, 343 S.C. 487, 541 S.E.2d 526 (2001).Â  Thus,
  because there was substantial evidence to support this finding, specifically
  Dr. Noojinâ€™s report, Employer claims the circuit court erred in reversing the
  finding of MMI.Â  However, Employer failed to appeal the circuit courtâ€™s finding
  the commissionâ€™s decision on permanent partial disability constituted a denial
  of Evansâ€™ due process.[4]Â 
  An unappealed ruling becomes the law of the case.Â  See Auto Owners
    Ins. Co. v. Langford, 330 S.C. 578, 583 n.2, 500 S.E.2d 496, 498 n. 2 (Ct.
  App. 1998) (noting trial courtâ€™s ruling on an issue becomes law of the case if
  appellant fails to take exception to it both before the trial court and on
  appeal).Â  Accordingly, we affirm the circuit courtâ€™s reversal and remand of the
  commissionâ€™s finding of MMI.Â   
CONCLUSION
On
  remand, we direct the commission to allow the parties to submit evidence and
  fully develop the record as to aggravation of any pre-existing conditions, the
  issue of permanent partial impairment and whether Evans has reached MMI.
Therefore,
  the circuit courtâ€™s order reversing the findings and conclusions of the commission
  are hereby
REVERSED IN PART, AFFIRMED IN PART, AND REMANDED. 

HUFF and PIEPER, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

[1] Employerâ€™s Insurance Carrier, Guide One Insurance
  Company, is also listed as an appellant to this action.
[2] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
[3] The
  accident report does not indicate whether Evans injured his right or left
  ankle.Â   
[4] Similarly, on appeal, Evans did not present the
  due process argument used by the circuit court.Â  Rather, Evans contends the
  circuit court properly reversed the finding of MMI because he was never
  provided treatment for his left lower extremity and thereby has not reached
  MMI.

title: Hess v. Norton
text:
THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				David L. Hess
      and Ceferina G. Hess, Appellants,
				v.
				Janice D.
      Norton and James C. Daniel (children of Jane D. Crum) and Russell M.
      Lawrence, Defendants,
				of whom:
				Janice D.
        Norton and James C. Daniel are Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenwood County
Wyatt T. Saunders, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-123
Submitted December 1, 2007 â€“ Filed
  February 19, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				David L. Hess and Ceferina G. Hess, Pro Se, of Greenwood, for Appellants.
				Donna J. Jackson, of Clinton, for Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  David
  and Ceferina Hess (Appellants) appeal the circuit courtâ€™s granting of summary
  judgment in favor of James Daniel and Janice Norton (collectively Heirs).Â  Appellants
  contend the oral statements made to them at the time of the purchase together
  with the subsequent sworn affidavit by Jane Crum are enough to support
  Appellantsâ€™ claim of title to the twelve and one-half feet of the alleyway
  located beyond the edge of their residence.Â  We affirm the circuit courtâ€™s grant
  of summary judgment.
FACTS
This matter arises from a property
  boundary dispute in Greenwood, South Carolina.Â  Mack and Jane Crum
  (collectively Crums) owned two parcels of land bordering Lawson Street.Â 
  Separating the two parcels in the rear of each is a twenty-five foot alleyway,
  which runs perpendicular to and dead ends into Lawson Street, extending in the
  opposite direction in a similar fashion between properties not subject to this
  suit.Â  In 1984, the Crums brought an action seeking to close the alley to public
  use, and transfer its ownership to the property owners.Â  In an order dated July
  23, 1984, Judge James E. Moore ruled in favor of the Crums, finding â€œthis
  street or alley [is] closed and that title to the twenty-five (25) foot width
  thereof shall rest in the abutting property owners to the center line thereof,
  that is, twelve and one-half (12.5) feet.â€Â  Significantly, the order referenced
  a 1927 plat prepared by T.C. Anderson, which found Crumâ€™s residence on one side
  of the alleyway encroached over the property line, and thus onto the alleyway,
  by 7.2 feet.Â  Because the Crums owned the properties on either side of the
  alleyway, title of the entire section of the alley between the two properties thereafter
  rested with them.
In
  1986, the Crums began renting the house located on one side of the alleyway to
  Appellants.Â  During the rental period, Appellants used the alleyway as a
  driveway to park their cars.Â  In May of 1988, Appellants purchased the same
  rental property from the Crums.Â  Included in the deed was the title to the 12.5
  feet or as much as would extend to the center line of the alleyway, and the
  deed specifically referenced the 1984 order of Judge Moore.Â  Additionally,
  Appellants admit their attorney examined the title to the subject property at
  the time of the purchase, and that they were aware of the 1984 order.Â   
Thereafter,
  the Crums indicated verbally, and Jane Crum committed to writing in an
  affidavit, that the sale of the property to Appellants included half the
  alleyway.Â  Further, it is uncontested that after the sale to Appellants, the
  Crums verbally and demonstrably indicated the extent of the alleyway intended
  to be included in the sale.Â  However, this oral indication was not memorialized
  until Jane Crum executed an affidavit in 1999.Â  Ms. Crum later recanted the
  affidavit, primarily because she admittedly had not seen the survey on record prior
  to signing the affidavit which showed Appellantsâ€™ residence encroached over
  their actual property boundary, 7.2 feet into the twenty-five foot alleyway.
In 1994, the Crums sold the remaining property located on the
  other side of the alleyway to Russell Lawrence.Â  Although it is not included in
  the record, testimony indicates Lawrence was given title to the other half of
  the twenty-five foot alleyway.Â  Shortly after his purchase, Lawrence erected a
  fence along the alleyway, and attempted to keep the Appellants off his
  property.Â  A property line dispute ensued, and Lawrence ordered a survey of the
  two lots by Eugene Adams, which revealed both that the alleyway was equally
  divided, and that Appellantâ€™s house extended over the property line into the
  alley.Â  The dispute between the two parties continued, and in 1999, Appellants
  commissioned a second survey by Adams.Â  The second survey similarly showed the
  divided alleyway, and an encroachment of 7.2 feet by the Appellantsâ€™ house into
  the alleyway, which corroborated the 1927 plat referenced in Judge Mooreâ€™s
  order.
As a result of the second survey, Appellants contacted Jane Crum
  in an attempt to memorialize the above-mentioned oral indication of Appellantsâ€™
  rights in the alleyway.Â  Ms. Crumâ€™s 1999 affidavit attests she and her husband
  â€œexplicitly showed and pointed . . . the extent of the alleyway included in the
  saleâ€ and references Judge Mooreâ€™s order for the proposition that the Crums had
  legal title in the alleyway to transfer.Â  In June of 2001, Appellants filed a
  complaint against Jane Crum, her husband being deceased, and Lawrence, seeking
  to reclaim the portion of the alleyway to which they believed they were
  entitled.Â  Pursuant to an agreement between the attorney for Lawrence and the attorney
  for Appellants at the time, the complaint against Lawrence was dismissed with
  prejudice on February 14, 2003.
It appears from the record that no request for a hearing was ever
  made, and in June of 2003, Jane Crum passed away.Â  Appellants were subsequently
  advised of Crumâ€™s death but appear not to have pursued the matter further.Â  On
  November 28, 2005, the circuit court judge dismissed the action, but allowed
  Appellants ninety days to substitute Crumâ€™s estate and personal representative
  in her place.Â  On January 27, 2006, Appellants, now acting pro se,
  filed a motion for a continuance, and a motion to substitute the Heirs as
  defendants.Â  At a hearing a month later, Judge Howard P. King granted both the
  motion for a thirty-day continuance, and the motion to substitute Crumâ€™s heirs
  in her stead.Â   
On April 4, 2006, Appellants filed an amended complaint
  substituting Heirs, as the children and surviving heirs of Crum, in addition to
  Lawrence, as defendants to the complaint.Â  Thereafter, Lawrence made a Rule 12(b)(6),
  SCRP, motion to dismiss based on res judicata, and Heirs made a Rule 56, SCRP,
  motion for summary judgment.Â  Both motions were granted, and Appellants appeal
  only the summary judgment motion in favor of Heirs.Â Â   
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion,
  this court applies the same standard of review as the trial court under Rule
  56, SCRCP.Â  Cowburn v. Leventis, 366 S.C. 20, 30, 619 S.E2d 437, 443
  (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Summary judgment is proper when there is no issue as to any
  material fact and the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of
  law.Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  Helms Realty, Inc. v. Gibson-Wall Co., 363 S.C.
  334, 340, 611 S.E.2d 485, 488 (2005).Â  To determine whether any triable issues
  of fact exist, the reviewing court must consider the evidence and all
  reasonable inferences in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Law
    v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corr., 368 S.C. 424, 434, 629 S.E.2d 642, 648 (2006).Â 
  When plain, palpable, and indisputable facts exist on which reasonable minds
  cannot differ, summary judgment should be granted.Â  Ellis v. Davidson,
  358 S.C. 509, 518, 595 S.E.2d 817, 822 (Ct. App. 2004).
On the other hand, summary judgment is not appropriate
  where further inquiry into the facts of the case is desirable to clarify the
  application of the law.Â  Vermeer Carolinaâ€™s, Inc. v. Wood/Chuck Chipper Corp.,
  336 S.C. 53, 59, 518 S.E.2d 301, 305 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  All ambiguities,
  conclusions, and inferences arising from the evidence must be construed most
  strongly against the moving party.Â  Bayle v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 344
  S.C. 115, 120, 542 S.E.2d 736, 738 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Even when there is no
  dispute as to evidentiary facts, but only as to the conclusions or inferences
  to be drawn from them, summary judgment should be denied.Â  See Hall
    v. Fedor, 349 S.C. 169, 173-74, 561 S.E.2d 654, 656 (Ct. App. 2002).Â 
  Summary judgment is a drastic remedy; it should therefore be cautiously invoked
  to prevent the improper deprivation of a trial of the disputed factual
  issues.Â Â  Lanham v. Blue Cross & Blue Shield, 349 S.C. 356, 363, 563
  S.E.2d 331, 336 (2002).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellants first
  contend the circuit court erred in granting summary judgment on the basis that the
  grant of use of the alleyway in perpetuity was not reduced to writing, as
  required by the Statute of Frauds.Â  Appellants contend the written deed of sale
  and Crumâ€™s 1999 affidavit referencing the twelve and one-half foot portion of
  the alleyway created a genuine issue of material fact.Â  We disagree.  
Section 27-35-20 of
  the South Carolina Code (1976) provides any agreement for the use or occupation
  of real estate for more than one year shall be void unless in writing.Â  It is
  established that Appellants received title to twelve and one-half feet of the
  alleyway that ran behind their property when the Crums sold the property to
  them in 1988.Â  However, it appears Appellants, deciding not to have the property
  surveyed at the time of purchase, believed that the twelve and one-half feet
  deeded to them began from the edge of their house and extended into the
  alleyway.Â  As described above, Appellantsâ€™ deed referenced Judge Mooreâ€™s order,
  in which then-petitioner Crum testified a portion of her residence encroached by
  some 7.2 feet into the twenty-five foot alleyway.Â   
Appellants contend
  the Crums orally represented to them that they had title in perpetuity to
  twelve and one-half feet, or to the center line, of the alleyway beginning at,
  and extending from the edge of the residence.Â  However, we find the deed and
  referenced plat to Appellants is clear that their title to the alleyway begins
  at the previous property line, and thus encompasses the 7.2 feet occupied by
  the residence.Â  Therefore, Appellantsâ€™ claim to the additional 7.2 feet of
  alleyway is based on the Crumâ€™s oral representations.Â  Because the oral
  agreement extending Appellantsâ€™ rights in the alleyway beyond the deed was made
  for more than one year, and was not memorialized in writing, it violated
  section 27-35-20. Â See Bruce v. Durney, 341 S.C. 563, 568, 534
  S.E.2d 720, 723 (Ct. of App. 2000) (finding a written rental agreement that
  allowed a tenancy to be created orally did not eliminate the need for a written
  agreement in order for a tenancy of more than one year to be valid under the
  Statute of Frauds).  
Appellants further
  maintain Jane Crumâ€™s 1999 affidavit satisfies the writing requirement of the
  statute of frauds while supplementing the existing deed and previous oral
  representations.Â  As a general rule, a memorandum may be made at any time
  subsequent to the execution of a contract and prior to the bringing of an
  action.Â  See Williston On Contracts, 4th Ed., Â§ 29:5 (2007); 72 Am. Jur.
  2d Statute of Frauds Â§Â§ 210 to 213 (2007); 37 C.J.S. Frauds, Statute of Â§ 104
  (2007).Â  While we acknowledge a proper memorandum evidencing an oral grant to
  Appellants, beyond that which was included in the deed, would be enough to
  satisfy the writing requirement in section 27-35-20, we find the 1999 affidavit
  does not meet these requirements.Â  â€œ[A] writing must reasonably identify the
  subject matter of the contract, sufficiently indicate a contract has been made
  between the parties, and state with reasonable certainty the essential terms of
  the agreement.â€Â  Player v. Chandler, 299 S.C. 101, 106, 382 S.E.2d 891,
  895 (1989) (citing Restatement (Second) of Contracts Â§ 131 (1981)).Â   
The 1999 affidavit before
  us appears to merely reiterate that the Crums showed and orally stated the extent
  of the alleyway included in the sale, and that it was the same as described in
  the survey plan, evidenced in the deed, and recorded in Judge Mooreâ€™s order.Â  It
  does not purport to give Appellants any more than was sold to them under the
  1986 deed.Â  As we decided above, the deed plainly gave Appellants only the
  twelve and one-half feet of the alleyway from the edge of their property line,
  and relies upon the order which takes note of the encroachment.Â  We therefore
  find Ms. Crumâ€™s 1999 affidavit is insufficient to qualify as a memorandum in
  support of the oral representation of any part of the alleyway in perpetuity
  beyond that which was explicated in the deed.
Appellants put
  forth several additional arguments on appeal.[1]Â 
  We find these arguments are neither preserved nor ruled upon, nor relevant to
  the circuit courtâ€™s determination of summary judgment before us.Â  Because we
  find the determination of the issue above to be dispositive in the appeal
  before us, we need not review Appellantsâ€™ remaining contentions. Â need not review remaining issues when its determination of a prior issue
  is dispositive of the appeal).
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we hold the circuit court did not err in
  granting summary judgment.Â  The decision of the circuit court is accordingly
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE, J., and THOMAS, J., concur.


[1] Appellants reference arguments submitted by Heirs in
  their motion for summary judgment, but upon which the circuit court did not
  rely in granting the motion.Â  These include:Â  (1) the action is not barred by
  the statute of limitations; (2) the action is not frivolous or based on a claim
  without merit; (3) that Heirsâ€™ contention the survey or plat of Lawrence be
  made the basis of his ownership is untenable; (4) Heirs have a responsibility
  to Appellants to oust Lawrence and BLT Properties as adverse possessors; and
  (5) Heirsâ€™ contention Appellants have failed to prosecute the case is without
  legal basis.

title: Anonymous Taxpayer v. South Carolina Department of Revenue
text:
THIS OPINION HAS
  NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE, IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Anonymous
      Taxpayer, Appellant,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				South Carolina
      Department of Revenue, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County
Â G. Thomas Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2008-UP-124
Submitted February 1, 2008 â€“ Filed
  February 20, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Emily T. Short, of Goose Creek, for
  Appellant.
				Ronald W. Urban, South Carolina Department of Revenue, of
  Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Anonymous
  Taxpayer (the taxpayer) appeals from a circuit court order dismissing her
  appeal from the administrative law court.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTUAL / PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Between
  January 1, 1996 and March 31, 1998, the taxpayer owned and operated Emilyâ€™s
  Temporary Housing, a sole-proprietorship.Â  On April 1, 1999, the taxpayer
  incorporated her business as Emilyâ€™s at Otranto, Inc., doing business as
  Emilyâ€™s Temporary Housing Service.Â  The taxpayerâ€™s businesses leased local
  houses and sublet the houses to individuals. Â Â In 2000, the Department
  of Revenue (the Department) conducted a sales and accommodations tax audit of
  the taxpayerâ€™s businesses.Â  During the audit, the Department determined the taxpayer
  sublet various properties for time periods less than ninety days and failed to
  remit the applicable taxes on the proceeds of the rentals.Â  The Department
  issued a proposed assessment to the sole-proprietorship in the amount of $13,093.41,
  and to the corporation in the amount of $2,873.02.Â   
The taxpayer
  requested a contested hearing before the Administrative Law Court (ALC). Â After
  a hearing, the ALC upheld the Departmentâ€™s assessments.Â  The taxpayer did not
  pay or post bond for the amount of tax and interest assessed by the Department.
  Â Instead, the taxpayer appealed to the circuit court. Â The Department filed a
  motion to dismiss.Â  By order of June 20, 2006, the circuit court granted the
  Departmentâ€™s motion.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW / ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Failure
  to Pay 
The taxpayer argues the circuit court erred
  in dismissing her appeal for failure to pay or post a bond for the amount of
  tax and interest determined to be due by the ALC. Â Â We disagree.
South
  Carolina Code Section 12-60-3370 states â€œ[a] taxpayer shall pay, or post bond for, all taxes, not
  including penalties or civil fines, determined to be due by the administrative
  law judge before appealing the decision to the circuit court.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann.
  Â§ 12-60-3370 (Supp. 2005).Â  The term â€œtaxâ€ or â€œtaxesâ€ is defined to include
  interest.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-60-30(27) (Supp. 2005).Â  A partyâ€™s failure to
  comply with such procedural requirements for an appeal divests a court of
  appellate jurisdiction.Â  State v. Brown, 358 S.C. 382, 387, 596 S.E.2d
  39, 41 (2004).
Here,
  the amount due from the taxpayer is a â€œtaxâ€ as defined in the South Carolina
  Revenue Procedures Act (the Act).Â  The Act defines â€œtaxâ€ or â€œtaxesâ€ as â€œtaxes, licenses, permits,
  fees, or other amounts, including interest, regulatory and other penalties, and
  civil fines, imposed by this title, or subject to assessment or collection by
  the Department.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-60-30(27).Â  Section 12-36-920 imposes â€œa
  sales tax equal to seven percent . . . on the gross proceeds derived from the
  rental . . . for any rooms, . . . lodgings, or sleeping accommodations
  furnished to transients.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-36-920.Â   
As stated above, taxpayer failed to pay the taxes
  attributable to her sole proprietorship and corporation prior to filing her
  appeal in the circuit court.Â  Accordingly, the circuit court properly dismissed
  the appeal for lack of appellate jurisdiction.
II.  Timeliness
The taxpayer further argues the circuit
  court erred in dismissing her appeal as untimely.Â  Because we affirm the
  circuit courtâ€™s order on the failure to pay issue, we decline to address this
  issue.Â  See Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mount Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406,
  423, 526 S.E.2d 716, 725 (2000) (holding the court need not address additional
  issues if the issues are not necessary to the resolution of the case).
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., PIEPER, J., and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: In the Matter of Outen
text:
THIS OPINION HAS
  NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE, IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				In 
				the Matter of the Care and Treatment of Kenneth Michael Outen, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From York County
Â James R. Barber, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2008-UP-125
Submitted February 1, 2008 â€“ Filed
  February 20, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Appellate Defender LaNelle C. DuRant, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Attorney General Deborah R.J. Shupe, Assistant
  Attorney General R. Westmoreland Clarkson, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Kenneth Michael Outen appeals his
  commitment to the South Carolina Department of Mental Health (the Department) as
  a sexually violent predator. We affirm.[1]
FACTUAL / PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In 1987, Outen pled guilty in North Carolina to sexually
  assaulting his thirteen-year-old stepdaughter. Â He was sentenced to four-and-one-half
  years imprisonment.  
In
  2001, Outen pled guilty in York County, South Carolina, to one count of a lewd
  act on a minor.Â  Outen admitted he molested an eleven-year-old female whom he
  babysat while her mother worked. Â Outen molested the child for three to four
  years prior to the incident that led to his arrest.Â   
Prior to Outenâ€™s scheduled release from prison,
  his case was referred to the sexually violent predator multi-disciplinary team because
  his conviction of lewd act on a minor is a qualifying offense under the
  Sexually Violent Predator Act (SVP Act).Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  44-48-30(2)(k) (Supp. 2006).Â  The multi-disciplinary team reviewed Outenâ€™s
  case, determined he satisfied the definition of a sexually violent predator,
  and forwarded his case to the prosecutorâ€™s review committee. Â The prosecutorâ€™s
  review committee agreed there was reason to believe Outen satisfied the
  criteria for commitment under the SVP Act. Â The State then filed a
  petition in circuit court to commit Outen to the Department for care and
  treatment as a sexually violent predator. Â After a hearing, the circuit
  court held probable cause existed to find Outen met the criteria for commitment
  and ordered that Outen be evaluated pursuant to the SVP Act.  
The
  matter was tried by a jury on October 11, 2005. Â Dr. Pamela Crawford
  testified for the State. Â She opined Outen suffered from nonexclusive
  pedophilia. Â Dr. Crawford defined pedophilia as a lifelong mental abnormality
  that causes one to have repetitive thoughts, behaviors, or fantasies involving
  sexual encounters with prepubescent children. Â She testified Outen has serious
  difficulty controlling his impulses and added, â€œ[Outenâ€™s difficulty controlling
  his impulses] is manifested by not simply [the fact] that he molested this one
  child, . . . but also that he again, even after having been sentenced and [serving
  time in] prison, . . . molested another child over a period of years.â€ Â Dr.
  Crawford stated it was her medical opinion that there existed a likelihood
  Outen would re-offend against young girls.Â  Â She concluded Outen met the
  requirements to be considered a sexually violent predator.  
After the state presented its case, Outen moved for a directed
  verdict. Â The circuit court denied the motion, finding the state presented
  evidence Outen met the criteria for commitment.Â   
Outen then presented the testimony of Dr. Thomas Martin.Â  He had
  conducted an independent evaluation of Outen.Â  Dr. Martin testified he
  diagnosed Outen as a pedophile. Â He added the following factors increase
  the likelihood Outen would re-offend: (1) he had more than one victim; (2) his
  victims were similar ages; and (3) he molested the victims on multiple occasions. Â Dr. Martin, however, opined Outen does not need to be confined in a
  secure facility for treatment. Â Instead, Dr. Martin stated Outen is â€œa
  very good candidate for out-patient treatment.â€  
At the close of all the evidence, Outen renewed his motion for a
  directed verdict.Â  The circuit court denied the motion, finding the State
  offered sufficient evidence to submit the case to the jury.Â   
The jury unanimously found Outen was a sexually violent predator
  under the SVP Act. Â Outen then moved for a judgment notwithstanding the
  verdict or for a new trial. Â The circuit court denied the motion, and
  ordered Outen committed to the Department of Mental Health.Â  Â Outen
  appeals.
LAW / ANALYSIS
Outen argues the trial court erred in
  denying his motion for a directed verdict because the State failed to present
  evidence beyond a reasonable doubt that Outen met the statutory definition of a
  sexually violent predator.Â  We disagree.
On an appeal from the trial courtâ€™s denial of a motion for a directed
  verdict, the appellate court may only reverse the trial court if there is no
  evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s ruling. Â State v. Gaster, 349 S.C.
  545, 555, 564 S.E.2d 87, 92 (2002).Â  In ruling on a directed verdict motion,
  the trial court is concerned with the existence of evidence, not its weight. Â Id.Â  
 
A sexually violent predator is defined in the SVP Act as â€œa person
  who (a) has been convicted of a sexually violent offense; and (b) suffers from
  a mental abnormality or personality disorder that makes the person likely to
  engage in acts of sexual violence if not confined in a secure facility for
  long-term control, care, and treatment.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-30(1) (Supp.
  2006). Â â€œMental abnormalityâ€ is defined as â€œa mental condition affecting a
  personâ€™s emotional or volitional capacity that predisposes the person to commit
  sexually violent offenses.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-30(3).Â  The phrase â€œlikely
  to engage in acts of sexual violenceâ€ is defined as a â€œpropensity to commit
  acts of sexual violence . . . of such a degree as to pose a menace to the
  health and safety of others.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-30(9).
Here, Outen pled guilty to committing a lewd act on a child, a
  sexually violent offense under the SVP Act.Â  See SC. Code Ann. Â§
  44-48-30 (2)(k).Â  Also, the record shows evidence Outen suffers from a mental
  abnormality or personality disorder, making him likely to engage in additional acts
  of sexual violence.Â  Â As set forth above, Dr. Crawford testified Outen suffers
  from pedophilia, which predisposes him to commit future acts of sexual
  violence. Â Dr. Crawford opined Outen met the criteria for commitment under the
  SVP Act. Â Also, Outenâ€™s expert, Dr. Martin, diagnosed Outen as a
  pediphile in need of treatment. Â Accordingly, the trial court did not err in
  denying Outenâ€™s motion for a directed verdict.
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., PIEPER, J. and GOOLSBY, A.J.,
  concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Massey v. Werner Enterprises, Inc.
text:
THIS OPINION HAS
  NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE, IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Marsha Elaine
      Massey, Employee, Respondent,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Werner
      Enterprises, Inc., Employer, and Liberty Mutual Insurance Corp., Carrier, Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Doyet A. Early, III, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-126
Heard February 5, 2008 â€“ Filed February
  20, 2008Â Â Â   

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Stanley T.
  Case, of Spartanburg, for Appellants.
				KathrynÂ  Williams, of Greenville, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: In
  this workersâ€™ compensation case, Werner Enterprises and Liberty Insurance
  Corporation appeal a circuit court order affirming the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commissionâ€™s
  award of benefits to Marsha Massey.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Marsha Massey and her husband own two transfer
  trucks. Â The Masseys began leasing one of the trucks to Werner Enterprises in
  2003. Â Werner subsequently hired the Masseys to drive the truck.  
On July 4, 2004, Massey sustained injuries when she slipped and fell
  from her truck while on a route for Werner in Arizona. Â Massey subsequently filed
  a workersâ€™ compensation claim against Werner and its carrier Liberty Insurance
  Company (collectively Appellants) in South Carolina. Â Appellants denied the
  claim, arguing Massey was an independent contractor and the South Carolina Workersâ€™
  Compensation Commission (the commission) lacked jurisdiction.  
After a hearing on October 6, 2005, the single commissioner found Massey suffered injuries
  while hauling goods for Werner. Â The single commissioner further found
  an employer-employee relationship existed between Werner and Massey. Â The single
  commissioner held the commission had jurisdiction because Massey was hired and
  employed in South Carolina. Â The single commissioner awarded Massey temporary
  total disability benefits and causally related medical expenses. The single commissioner
  awarded benefits based on an average weekly wage of $667.11.Â   
Appellants appealed to the appellate panel. Â The appellate
  panel affirmed the single commissionerâ€™s findings. Â Appellants then
  sought judicial review in the circuit court. Â The circuit court affirmed the
  order of the appellate panel on all issues. Â Appellants appeal.
LAW / ANALYSIS
1.Â Â Appellants argue the appellate panel erred in concluding
  Massey was entitled to benefits because an employer-employee relationship did
  not exist between Werner and Massey.[1]Â 
  In support of their assertion, Appellants heavily rely on the owner-operator
  agreement Massey entered into with Werner, Masseyâ€™s declaration of employment
  status as an independent contractor, and the Nebraska owner-operator workersâ€™
  compensation coverage agreement signed by Massey.Â   
Although the partiesâ€™ contract must be considered in determining
  the nature of their relationship, the description of the relationship set forth
  in the contract is not dispositive.Â  Kilgore Group, Inc. v. S.C. Employment
    Sec. Commâ€™n., 313 S.C. 65, 68-69, 437 S.E.2d 48, 50 (1993).Â  Rather, the
  test to determine whether an employer-employee relationship exists is if the
  alleged employer has the right and authority to control and direct the
  particular work or undertaking, as to the manner or means of its
  accomplishment.Â  S.C. Workersâ€™ Comp, Commâ€™n v. Ray Covington Realtors, Inc.,
  318 S.C. 546, 547, 459 S.E.2d 302, 303 (1995).Â  The following four factors are
  evaluated to determine the right to control: (1) direct evidence of the right
  or exercise of control; (2) method of payment; (3) furnishing of equipment; and
  (4) right to fire.Â  Tharpe v. G.E. Moore Co., 254 S.C. 196, 200, 174
  S.E.2d 397, 399 (1970).Â  Any single factor is sufficient proof of the
  employment relationship; however, the absence of any one of the factors is at
  most only mildly persuasive evidence of contractorship.Â  See Nelson
    v. Yellow Cab Co., 349 S.C. 589, 594-95, 564 S.E.2d 110, 113 (2002); Wilkinson
      v. Palmetto State Transp. Co., 371 S.C. 365, 373, 638 S.E.2d 109, 114 (Ct. App. 2006) cert. pending.Â  
 
Here, direct evidence shows Werner had the right to control and
  direct Masseyâ€™s work.Â  Although Massey owned the tractor, Werner did not allow Massey to drive the
  truck for personal errands or for any other company. Â Moreover, Werner required Massey to affix Werner
  logos on the truck and install a computer communication device in her truck.Â 
  Werner used the device to control Masseyâ€™s activities by tracking the location of the truck and instructing
  Massey regarding the pick-up and delivery of loads. Â Werner required Massey to
  use pre-approved fuel stops and service shops. Â This requirement directed
  Masseyâ€™s route as Werner considered Massey off route if she failed to use the
  pre-approved stops. Â Werner further required Massey to use a company credit
  card for fuel and service charges, and these charges were deducted from Masseyâ€™s
  pay.  
Werner also furnished Masseyâ€™s equipment.Â  Werner leased the
  tractor from Massey, supplied the trailer, and prohibited Massey from driving
  the truck for any other company.Â  In addition, Werner provided permits, the logos
  affixed to the tractor, and the computer communication device.Â  See Wilkinson, 371 S.C. at 374, 638 S.E.2d at 114
  (stating employer supplied equipment where employer provided trailer, logos,
  and a global positioning system).
Finally, Werner asserted control over Masseyâ€™s work by maintaining
  the authority to terminate Massey at any time.Â  See Tharpe, 254
  S.C. at 201, 174 S.E.2d at 399 (stating the unconditional power to terminate
  employment is consistent with an employer-employee relationship).Â  Massey
  testified both she and Werner could terminate the agreement at any time without
  penalty. Â Massey further testified Werner could terminate the
  relationship if Massey took off more than four consecutive days.  
The foregoing factors all indicate an
  employer-employee relationship existed between Werner and Massey.Â  Accordingly,
  we affirm the circuit courtâ€™s determination on this issue.
2.Â Â Appellants next assert Massey is not entitled to benefits
  in South Carolina because she received coverage under Nebraska law.Â  This
  assertion is without merit.Â  Claimants who
  accept workersâ€™ compensation benefits in another state are not precluded from
  seeking additional benefits for which they are authorized to file in South Carolina. Â Holman v. Bulldog Trucking Co.  311 S.C. 341, 344, 428 S.E.2d
  889, 891 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  Furthermore, the Nebraska workersâ€™ compensation
  coverage agreement does not operate to prohibit coverage in South Carolina.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-610 (2004) (stating no contract shall operate to relieve
  an employer of any obligation created by the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act); S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-620 (Supp. 2006) (stating an agreement by an employee to waive
  his rights under the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act is void).  
3.Â Â Appellants argue the appellate panel lacked jurisdiction
  over Masseyâ€™s claim for benefits because Werner hired Massey in Georgia, Wernerâ€™s home office is located in Nebraska, and the injury occurred in Arizona.Â  We
  disagree.
An injured worker can file a claim under the laws of the state where
  he is hired, he is injured, or his employment is located.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-10 (Supp. 2006).Â  Here, South Carolina is the state of
  hire.Â  Massey accepted the position by telephone while in her home in South Carolina.Â  See Oâ€™Briant v. Daniel Constr. Co., 279 S.C. 254, 256, 305
  S.E.2d 241, 243 (1983) (holding the existence of a contract establishes the
  employer-employee relationship; where acceptance is given by telephone, the
  place of contracting is where the acceptor speaks his acceptance).Â  In
  addition, Masseyâ€™s employment was located in South Carolina.Â  Massey parked her
  truck at her home in South Carolina when she was not driving.Â  See Holman,
  311 S.C. at 346, 428 S.E.2d at 892 (stating employment is located in the state
  of the employeeâ€™s base of operations); See also Hill v. Eagle
    Motor Lines, 373 S.C. 422, 432, 645 S.E.2d 424, 429 (2007) (finding a truck
  driverâ€™s base of operations was in South Carolina because he received work
  assignments from his South Carolina home, started his road trips from his home,
  kept his truck at his home on the weekends, and received his paycheck at home).Â 
  Furthermore, Massey testified Werner told her she would be based out of her
  home because Werner does not have a South Carolina facility.Â   
4.Â Â Appellants argue the appellate panel erred in determining
  Masseyâ€™s weekly wage and compensation rate.Â  We find substantial evidence
  supports the appellate panelâ€™s findings.
A claimantâ€™s average weekly wage is generally calculated by
  dividing the claimantâ€™s actual earnings in the four quarters prior to the
  injury by fifty-two weeks.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-40 (Supp.
  2006).Â  Where the claimant worked only a short period of time prior to the
  injury, the wage can be calculated using the wage of a similarly situated
  employee.Â  Id.Â  Where the wage cannot be calculated using either of the
  foregoing methods, â€œsuch other method . . . may be resorted to as will most
  nearly approximate the amount which the injured employee would be earning were
  it not for the injury.â€Â  Id.Â  The purpose of the average weekly wage
  statute is to â€œarrive at a fair approximation of the claimantâ€™s probable future
  earning capacity.â€Â  Sellers v. Pinedale Residential Ctr., 350 S.C. 183,
  191, 564 S.E.2d 694, 699 (Ct. App. 2002).Â   
Here, the appellate panel was not able to compute Masseyâ€™s wages
  using the two methods provided in the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act because Massey
  worked for a short amount of time prior to her injury, and Werner did not
  provide the commission with wage information.Â  Accordingly, the appellate panel
  did not err in using statistical information for truck drivers in the Greenville area to approximate Masseyâ€™s weekly wage and compensation rate.Â  
 
AFFIRMED.
HUFF AND PIEPER, JJ. and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur.Â 

[1]Â  Appellants also assert the appellate panel erred in
  finding Werner is Masseyâ€™s statutory employer.Â  We decline to address this
  issue because we find Werner was Masseyâ€™s direct employer.

PER CURIAM: Antwan Salters pled guilty to murder, armed robbery,

title: Witherspoon Wilson Associates v. Lexington County Community Mental Health Center
text:
THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Witherspoon
      Wilson Associates, Respondent,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Lexington County Community Mental Health Center, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Lexington County
Â Clyde N. Davis, Jr., Special Circuit Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-130
Heard February 5, 2008 â€“ Filed February
  20, 2008Â Â Â  
REVERSED AND REMANDED


	
		
			
				Mark W. Binkley and R. Alan Powell, both of Columbia, for
  Appellant.
				David Andrew Maxfield and John S. Nichols, both of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: In
  this breach of contract action, Lexington County Community Mental Health Center (the Center) appeals the grant of partial summary judgment to Witherspoon
  Wilson Associates (the Lessor).Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTS
The Center, an outpatient facility of the
  South Carolina Department of Mental Health (SCDMH), entered into a seven-year
  lease (the Lease) with the Lessor, a developer and manager of commercial real
  estate and investment property. The leased property was a commercial building
  located in West Columbia, South Carolina.Â  The lease term was to commence March
  1, 2001, and end on February 29, 2008.Â Â   
During
  the lease term, the Center entered into lease agreements with two additional lessors.Â  In July 2003, the Center entered into a lease, effective August 1,
  2003, with Saluda Ridge, LLC for premises at 215 Palmetto Park, Lexington, South Carolina.Â  In September 2003, the Center entered into a lease, effective
  September 1, 2003, with the Michael and Helen Masters Family Trust for premises
  at 3965 Fish Hatchery Road, Gaston, South Carolina.Â  Over the next several
  months the Center continued to pay the Lessor rent under the Lease, but began
  moving various programs from the Lessorâ€™s building to property either owned by
  the Center and SCDMH, or the recently leased properties at Palmetto Park and Fish Hatchery Road.Â  On February 20, 2004, Mr. Richard Acton, the Centerâ€™s
  Executive Director, sent a letter to the Lessor giving notice that the Center
  was cancelling the Lease pursuant to Paragraph 6(f).Â   
Paragraph 6 of the lease, entitled â€œLESSEE CANCELLATION,â€ contained
  six provisions allowing the Center to cancel the Lease prior to the end of the
  lease term.Â  Paragraph 6(f) provides:  

	After applicable written notice to Lessor, [the Center] may cancel
  this lease without penalty, charge or further obligation:
	(f) after the first six (6) months from commencement date, by
  giving one hundred twenty days written notice, provided that the OCCUPANT moves
  into a building owned, leased or otherwise controlled by [the Center],
  SCDMH or any other public agency or entity. 
	(emphasis added)

After providing notice of cancellation, the Center paid rent for
  another 120 days, but thereafter ceased paying rent.Â  The Lessor brought an
  action for breach of contract against the Center.Â  The master, sitting as a
  special circuit judge, heard the matter upon a motion for partial summary
  judgment filed by the Lessor.Â  The judge found the Centerâ€™s interpretation of
  the cancellation provision â€œabsurd,â€ for under such a reading â€œthere would
  literally be no circumstance under which [the Center] could not unilaterally
  cancel the lease simply by moving out and renting any other space that it
  preferred.â€ Â In making the determination, the judge applied contract
  construction principles. As a further basis for the ruling, the judge found
  Paragraph 6(f), at a minimum, was ambiguous â€œin its meaning or application.â€Â 
  Thus, the judge construed the clause against the Center, as the drafter of the
  Lease, and granted partial summary judgment in favor of the Lessor.Â  This
  appeal follows.Â   
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When
  reviewing the grant of summary judgment, an appellate court applies the same
  standard that governs the trial court under Rule 56, SCRCP: summary judgment is
  proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving
  party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Moore v. Weinberg,
  373 S.C. 209, 215, 644 S.E.2d 740, 743 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  In determining whether
  any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all reasonable inferences
  therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Osborne
    v. Adams, 346 S.C. 4, 7, 550 S.E.2d 319, 321 (2001).Â   
Summary judgment is
  appropriate if the pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and
  admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no
  genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to
  judgment as a matter of law.Â  Rule 56 (c), SCRCP;Â  Moore, 373 S.C. at
  215, 644 S.E.2d at 743.Â  Summary judgment is not appropriate where further
  inquiry into the facts of the case is desirable to clarify the application of
  the law.Â  Id.Â  Summary judgment is a drastic remedy that should be
  cautiously invoked in order not to improperly deprive a litigant of a trial on
  the disputed factual issues.Â  Murray v. Holnam, Inc., 344 S.C.
  129, 138, 542 S.E.2d 743, 747 (Ct. App. 2001).Â   
LAW/ANALYSIS
The
  Center contends summary judgment was improper because the court found the
  cancellation provision under Paragraph 6(f) ambiguous.Â  Alternatively, the
  Center argues if the cancellation provision under Paragraph 6(f) is not
  ambiguous, summary judgment in favor of the Lessor was improper because the
  Center did not breach the lease.  
Where
  a motion for summary judgment presents a question as to the construction of a
  written contract, if the language employed by the agreement is plain and
  unambiguous, the question is one of law and can be properly disposed of at
  summary judgment.Â  Hansen v. United Services Automobile Assoc., 350 S.C.
  62, 67, 565 S.E.2d 114, 116 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  However, where the motion for
  summary judgment presents a question as to the construction of a written
  contract, and the contract is ambiguous because the intent of the parties
  cannot be gathered from the four corners of the instrument, summary judgment is
  improper.Â  Gilliland v. Elmwood Properties, 301 S.C. 295, 299, 391
  S.E.2d 577, 579 (1990).Â  An ambiguous contract is a contract capable of being
  understood in more than one way or a contract unclear in meaning because it
  expresses its purpose in an indefinite manner.Â  Klutts Resort Realty, Inc.
    v. Downâ€™Round Dev. Corp., 268 S.C. 80, 89, 232 S.E.2d 20, 25 (1977).Â  
 
In this case, on a motion for
  summary judgment, the court found Paragraph 6(f) created an ambiguity â€œin its
  meaning [and] application.â€Â  The court further found the
  Centerâ€™s interpretation of the cancellation provision â€œabsurdâ€ and utilized
  principles of contract construction to resolve the ambiguity instead of
  proceeding to a hearing on the merits.Â  Where a contract is ambiguous and
  capable of more than one construction, the matter is one to be determined by
  the fact finder.Â  See e.g. HK New Plan Exchange Property Owner
    I, LLC v. Coker, 375 S.C. 18, 23, 649 S.E.2d 181, 184 (Ct. App. 2007); Wheeler
      v. Globe Rutgers Fire Ins. Co. of City of N.Y., 125 S.C. 320, 325, 118 S.E.
  609, 610 (1923).Â  Therefore, we find the court improperly resolved the
  ambiguity on summary judgment.[1]Â  In light of our disposition, we need not address the
  Centerâ€™s remaining issue.Â  See Whiteside v. Cherokee County Sch. Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 340-41, 428 S.E.2d 886, 889 (1993) (appellate
  court need not address a remaining issue when resolution of prior issue is
  dispositive).Â  Accordingly, the decision is  
REVERSED
  AND REMANDED.Â Â  
HUFF and PIEPER,
  JJ, and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur. 

[1] We note that it is possible for a court to reject an
  absurd interpretation as a matter of law.Â  Holden v. Alice Mfg., Inc.,
  317 S.C. 215, 221, 452 S.E.2d 628, 631 (Ct. App. 1994) (finding a contract must
  be interpreted in its natural and ordinary sense, such that it receive
  â€œsensible and reasonable construction and not such construction as will lead to
  absurd consequences or unjust results.â€).Â  At oral argument, we questioned
  counsel as to whether the matter was submitted for a decision on the merits as
  opposed to a decision based solely on summary judgment principles. While this
  court received conflicting responses, we must base our decision on the record
  which does not indicate the matter was postured as a â€œmeritsâ€ decision to the
  trial court.Â  Before the judge reached a decision as to which interpretation to
  adopt, he concluded an ambiguity existed that would allow for him to consider either
  opposing interpretations or the intention of the parties; absent an agreement
  to do so, these matters are not properly resolved by summary judgment.

THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Jimmy L. Owens,
      Jr., Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Horry County
John L. Breeden, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-131
Heard February 12, 2008 â€“ Filed February
  20, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Appellate Defender LaNelle C. DuRant, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant
  Attorney General Deborah R. J. Shupe, all of Columbia; and Solicitor John
  Gregory Hembree, of Conway, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  A jury found Jimmy Owens, Jr. guilty of criminal
  sexual conduct (CSC) with a minor in the first degree and lewd act on a minor.Â 
  The trial court sentenced Owens to thirty years for the CSC charge and fifteen
  years for the lewd act to run consecutively.Â  Owens appeals the trial courtâ€™s
  admission of evidence and qualification of an expert witness.Â  We affirm.
1.Â Owens argues the
  trial court erred in admitting a recorded phone call Owens made to his mother
  while incarcerated.Â  At trial, counsel for Owens argued the tape recording was
  prejudicial and did not constitute a statement against interest.Â  Rule 801
  (d)(2), SCRE allows the admission of a statement offered against a
  party if the statement is â€œthe partyâ€™s own statement in either an individual or
  a representative capacity.â€Â  At the beginning of the phone
  call, a recording alerted Owens the call is subject to monitoring and
  recording; however, Owens still made admissions.Â  Owens said the State would
  argue the victimâ€™s mother was at fault.Â  Owens stated, among other things, â€œ[b]ecause
  she [victimâ€™s mother] knew what I were (sic) before I come in the house.Â 
  Therefore, she give (sic) me ample opportunity to mess with them kids.â€Â 
  Despite Owensâ€™s contention otherwise, this recording could be reasonably
  construed as containing inculpatory evidence.Â  Therefore, the trial court did
  not abuse its discretion.
2.Â Owens contends the
  trial court abused its discretion in certifying Cathie Coons, a forensic interviewer,
  as an expert.Â  Coonsâ€™s extensive experience indicates no abuse of discretion
  was made.Â  Coons received
  certification from professional societies, conducted over 400 forensic
  interviews, observed over 400 forensic interviews, attended training programs,
  and testified multiple times in family court as an expert in forensic interviews.Â  See Gooding v. St. Francis Xavier Hosp., 326 S.C. 248, 252-53,
  487 S.E.2d 596, 598 (1997) (â€œ[A] witness must have acquired by reason of study
  or experience or both such knowledge and skill in a profession or science that
  he is better qualified than the jury to form an opinion on the particular
  subject of his testimony.â€).Â  Additionally, Coonsâ€™s testimony regarding the victimâ€™s
  interview was merely cumulative to the victimâ€™s testimony before the trial
  court.
3.Â Owens additionally
  assigns error to the trial courtâ€™s sua sponte questioning of Coons,
  while in the juryâ€™s presence, as to whether Coons believed the victim was
  telling the truth.Â  Coons responded in the affirmative.Â  We decline to address
  this issue because a contemporaneous objection was not made at trial.Â  See State v. Johnson, 363 S.C. 53, 58, 609 S.E.2d 520, 523 (2005) (requiring a
  contemporaneous objection with specificity for the issue to be preserved).
Accordingly,
  we affirm the trial courtâ€™s admittance of the recording and certification of Coons
  as an expert.
AFFIRMED.
HUFF, KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.
