title: Campagna v. Flowers
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Joyce G.
      Campagna and Donald C. Campagna, Appellants,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				George F.
      Flowers, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Charleston County
Thomas L. Hughston, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-132
Heard January 8, 2008 â€“ Filed February 27,
  2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Desa Ballard and Christopher Smith, Jr., both of West Columbia and
  Â Reese I. Joye, of N. Charleston, for Appellants.
				William O. Sweeny, III, and William R. Calhoun, both of Columbia,
  for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  In
  this personal injury action arising from a car accident in downtown Charleston,
  Plaintiffs Joyce G. Campagna (Campagna) and Donald C. Campagna appeal the
  verdict for Defendant George Flowers and the denial of their motion for a new
  trial absolute, arguing the trial court improperly admitted DVD evidence
  recorded several years after the incident.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On September 19, 2001, after leaving work
  at 5:00 p.m., Campagna drove down Bee Street to the Lockwood Boulevard
  intersection, stopped at a red light, looked both ways, and then successfully
  made a right turn on red onto Lockwood Boulevard.Â  About the same time, Flowers
  was approaching the Lockwood Boulevard intersection from the opposite direction
  on an off-ramp from Highway 17.Â  He was stopped at the same red light across
  the same intersection and, when the light changed to the green arrow, turned
  left onto Lockwood Boulevard, thus preparing to travel in the same direction in
  which Campagna was proceeding.Â  After both Campagna and Flowers completed their
  turns, their vehicles collided.
On
  December 23, 2003, Campagna filed this action against Flowers for injuries she
  allegedly suffered from the accident.Â  Donald Campagna also sued for loss of
  consortium.Â  Flowers timely answered the Campagnasâ€™ complaint, denying liability.Â 
 
The
  matter was tried before a jury from April 12 through April 14, 2006.Â  The
  primary factual dispute in the matter was whether the collision occurred in the
  curb lane or in the middle lane.[1]Â 
  Whereas Campagna contended Flowers improperly changed lanes and hit her vehicle
  while she was traveling in the curb lane, Flowers maintained Campagna
  improperly changed lanes and collided with his vehicle while he was driving in
  the middle lane.Â   
At
  trial, the Campagnas offered photographs taken a few days after the accident
  showing all directions of the accident scene.Â  To combat this testimony,
  Flowers offered a DVD of traffic moving in the intersection on October 26,
  2006.Â  The Campagnas objected to this evidence, arguing (1) the DVD documented
  the intersection more than four years after the accident; (2) the accident
  scene was substantially different from what it had been at the time of the
  accident; and (3) the DVD showed cars repeatedly making illegal turns similar
  to what Flowers alleged Campagna had made.Â  Over these objections, the trial
  court allowed the jury to view the DVD.Â   
The
  jury returned a verdict for Flowers.Â  Following the denial of their post-trial
  motions, the Campagnas filed this appeal.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œ[T]he admission or
  exclusion of evidence in general is within the sound discretion of the trial
  court.â€Â  Fields v. Regâ€™l Med. Ctr. of Orangeburg, 363 S.C. 19, 25, 609
  S.E.2d 506, 509 (2005).Â  â€œThe trial court has wide discretion in determining
  the relevancy of evidence.â€Â  Wright v. Craft, 372 S.C. 1, 33, 640 S.E.2d
  486, 503 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  For an appellate court to reverse a case based on
  the erroneous admission or exclusion of evidence, the appealing party must show
  prejudice.Â  Hanahan v. Simpson, 326 S.C. 140, 155-56, 485 S.E.2d 903,
  911 (1997).Â   
â€œError
  may not be predicated upon a ruling which admits or excludes evidence unless a
  substantial right of the [complaining] party is affected.â€Â  Rule 103, SCRE.Â 
  For a substantial right to be affected, there must be â€œa reasonable probability the juryâ€™s verdict was influenced by
  the challenged evidence or the lack thereof.â€Â  Fields, 363 S.C. at 26,
  609 S.E.2d at 509.Â  â€œA reasonable probability is a probability sufficient to
  undermine confidence in the outcome of the trial.â€Â  Johnson v. State,
  325 S.C. 182, 186, 480 S.E.2d 733, 735 (1997).
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â  The Campagnas first argue
  the DVD was not relevant because it â€œdid not make any fact more or less
  probable.â€Â  We disagree.Â   
The
  DVD was admitted as demonstrative evidence and shown to the jury just before
  the defense called the police officer who had responded to the accident.Â 
  Before it was played, the trial court explained to the jury that the purpose of
  showing it was â€œjust so you can see and get a better feel and knowledge of the
  intersection from various angles.â€Â  The court further cautioned the jury that
  the DVD was not made on the day of the accident and the intersection had
  changed since that time, but also noted the roadway itself was still
  substantially the same.Â  The DVD had secondary relevance to the case and, when
  considered with the officerâ€™s testimony, enabled the jury to understand the officerâ€™s
  description of various roads in and around the intersection.Â  We therefore find
  no abuse of discretion in the trial courtâ€™s decision to admit the DVD into
  evidence.Â  See Clark v. Cantrell, 339 S.C. 369, 383, 529 S.E.2d
  528, 535 (2000) (noting demonstrative evidence â€œexplains or summarizes other
  evidence and testimony,â€ â€œhas secondary relevance to the issues at hand,â€ and â€œis
  not directly relevant, but must rely on other material testimony for relevanceâ€); Davis v. Traylor, 340 S.C. 150, 156-57, 530 S.E.2d 385, 388-89 (Ct. App.
  2000) (noting an â€œabuse of discretionâ€ standard applies to a trial courtâ€™s
  decision regarding both the exhibiting and admission of demonstrative
  evidence).Â  The changes in the intersection between the time of the accident
  and the recording of the DVD would at most have affected the weight of the
  evidence, not its admissibility.
2.Â  The Campagnas next argue
  that admission of the DVD was unduly prejudicial, noting it showed numerous
  vehicles making illegal turns similar to the turn that Flowers alleged Campagna
  had made. Â The Campagnas contend the prejudice was exacerbated by the likelihood
  that the vehicles depicted in the DVD were attempting to avoid striking a
  curb-edged covered walkway that was admittedly not in place on the day of the
  accident.Â  We find no error.Â  The DVD also depicted a number of vehicles
  intruding or going into the far right lane while making the same left turn that
  Flowers made from Highway 17 onto Lockwood Boulevard.Â  We therefore cannot say
  the DVD favored either sideâ€™s version of how the accident occurred.Â   
3.Â  We decline to address the
  Campagnasâ€™ argument that the DVD was misleading because it did not contain a
  continuous representation of the intersection of traffic patterns or their
  allegation that, as evidenced by the constant changing of vantage points and
  sporadic time stamps, it was edited to characterize Campagnaâ€™s conduct as
  illegal.Â  We have found no indication in either the record or the briefs that
  these concerns were raised at trial, and Campagnaâ€™s attorney indicated during
  oral argument that they were first raised to the trial court during post-trial
  motions; therefore, they were not raised in a timely manner and were not
  preserved for appeal. Â See Hickman v. Hickman, 301 S.C. 455, 456,
  392 S.E.2d 481, 482 (Ct. App. 1990) (â€œA party cannot
  use Rule 59(e) to present to the court an issue the party could have raised prior
  to judgment but did not.â€).
CONCLUSION
We hold
  the Campagnas failed to show the trial court committed reversible error in
  admitting the DVD evidence submitted by Flowers and are therefore not entitled
  to a new trial absolute.
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., KITTREDGE and THOMAS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  As the Campagnasâ€™ attorney explained during opening
  argument, the part of Lockwood Boulevard that both Campagna and Flowers entered
  had three lanes.Â  Both Campagna and Flowers acknowledged the lane closest to
  the center line was a left-turn only lane.

title: State v. Hungerford
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Appellant,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Phillips
      Hungerford, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
Â John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-133
Submitted February 1, 2008 â€“ Filed
  February 27, 2008Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior
  Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, Office of the Attorney
  General, all of Columbia;Â  and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for
  Appellant.
				Howard W. Paschal, Jr. and Catherine O. Fayssoux, both of Greenville, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  The
  State appeals the circuit courtâ€™s reversal of Hungerfordâ€™s driving under the
  influence (DUI) conviction arguing it was based on a ground not raised during
  the trial before the magistrate court.Â  We affirm.[1]  
FACTS
In the
  early morning hours of October 7, 2001, Phillips Hungerford was returning home
  after attending a wedding reception.Â Â  Russell Thompson, a State Trooper with
  the South Carolina Highway Patrol, followed Hungerford as he drove through a
  construction zone on Highway 291, a highway with three lanes of travel in each
  direction.Â  Trooper Thompson noticed Hungerford having trouble â€œmaintaining his
  laneâ€ of travel.Â  Initially, Trooper Thompson attributed Hungerfordâ€™s improper
  driving to confusion in negotiating the construction zone.Â  Trooper Thompson
  continued to follow Hungerford and observed him driving erratically after
  leaving the construction zone.Â  This prompted Trooper Thompson to initiate a
  traffic stop.Â  During the traffic stop, Trooper Thompson had Hungerford attempt
  two field sobriety tests.Â  Hungerford failed both tests.Â  As a result,
  Hungerford was placed under arrest for Driving Under the Influence.Â   
On September
  22, 2005, Hungerford had a jury trial in magistrate court for the DUI offense. Â Prior
  to jury selection, Hungerfordâ€™s attorney made a motion to exclude video footage
  of his client, which had been made at the time of and following his arrest.Â 
  The video footage was contained on two tapes.Â  The first video tape begins with
  Trooper Thompsonâ€™s initial questioning of Hungerford during the traffic stop
  and continues until Trooper Thompson and Hungerford arrive at the county jail.Â 
 
The second video tape, which was made at the county jail, shows
  Trooper Thompsonâ€™s attempts at getting Hungerford to take a Datamaster/Breathalyzer
  test.Â  At the beginning of the second video tape, Trooper Thompson advises
  Hungerford of his Miranda[2] rights.Â  The second video tape includes Hungerford attempting to invoke his
  right to counsel seventeen times.Â  Hungerford makes numerous statements which
  are similar to â€œI am not refusing to take the test. I am saying I want to talk
  to my attorney before I take the test.â€Â  Trooper Thompson interprets
  Hungerfordâ€™s invocations as refusals to take the Datamaster/Breathalyzer test.Â 
  The video tape shows Trooper Thompson informing Hungerford he has refused to
  take the test.Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
During the pre-trial motion hearing before the magistrate, Hungerfordâ€™s
  attorney argued, inter alia, the footage should be excluded â€œas a
  violation of [Hungerfordâ€™s] Fifth Amendment rights, and the Miranda warnings, and in particular the portion of the tape after the arrest.â€Â  The
  magistrate ruled the tapes were admissible and replied to Hungerfordâ€™s
  attorney: â€œI understand. Youâ€™re preserved well on the record, Counsel, and Iâ€™ll
  be glad - - Iâ€™ll look forward to hearing from the appeals in this matter so
  that we can get some better guidance.â€Â Â Â Â  Â Â 
Trooper Thompson was the first witness called during the trial.Â  At
  the conclusion of his testimony, both video tapes were played for the jury. The
  jury found Hungerford guilty.Â  Hungerford appealed his conviction to the
  circuit court arguing, inter alia, his invocation of rights guaranteed
  under Miranda, after being advised of a right to invoke said rights,
  prohibited the introduction at trial of: 1) the fact that he invoked his right
  to counsel; and 2) the fact that he refused to take the Datamaster/Breathalyzer
  test based on the Stateâ€™s refusal to allow him to speak with counsel.[3]Â  Hungerford argued the fact that he
  the invoked his Miranda rights, after being advised of said rights,
  could not be used against a him at trial given the United States Supreme Courtâ€™s
  holding in Doyle v. Ohio, 426 U.S. 610, 96 S.Ct. 2240 (1976).Â   
The State argued, inter alia, Hungerfordâ€™s issues on appeal
  had not been raised below and, therefore, were not preserved for appeal.Â  The
  State contended the arguments made during the motion hearing were limited to
  the first video tape, Hungerfordâ€™s attorney had not mentioned Doyle during the proceedings before the magistrate, and Hungerfordâ€™s attorney failed
  to make a contemporaneous objection to the second video tape when it was introduced
  at trial.Â Â  Hungerfordâ€™s attorney countered that because Hungerford waived his
  rights in the first video tape, the only Constitutional or Miranda issue
  in the case was in the second video tape and, accordingly, the second video
  tape was target for his objection.Â  Â Â 
After
  considering the wording of Hungerfordâ€™s objection at the motion hearing, the
  magistrateâ€™s assurance that Hungerfordâ€™s arguments were understood and preserved,
  and the fact that the only Constitutional or Miranda issue in the case
  was in the second video tape, the circuit court found Hungerfordâ€™s arguments
  were preserved for appeal.Â  The circuit court reversed Hungerfordâ€™s conviction
  and ordered the matter remanded for a new trial.Â  This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Appeals
  from magistrate court convictions are made to the circuit court. S.C. Code Ann.
  Â§ 18-3-10 (Supp. 2006). The circuit court, acting as the appellate court,
  reviews the matters raised in the notice of appeal. S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 18-3-70
  (Supp. 2006) (â€œThe appeal must be heard by the Court of Common Pleas upon the
  grounds of exceptions made and upon the papers required under this chapter,
  without the examination of witnesses....â€). â€œIn criminal appeals from
  magistrate or municipal court, the circuit court does not conduct a de novo review, but instead reviews for preserved error raised to it by appropriate
  exception.â€Â  State v. Henderson, 347 S.C. 455, 457, 556 S.E.2d 691, 692
  (Ct. App. 2001). Â An issue is not preserved when one ground is raised to
  the trial court and another ground is raised on appeal. State v. Freiburger,
  366 S.C. 125, 134, 620 S.E.2d 737, 741 (2005).Â  â€œConstitutional issues, like
  most others, must be raised to and ruled upon by the trial court to be
  preserved for appeal.â€ In re Care & Treatment of Corley, 365 S.C.
  252, 258, 616 S.E.2d 441, 444 (Ct. App. 2005). Â In
  criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only. State
    v. Baccus, 367 S.C. 41, 48, 625 S.E.2d 216, 220 (2006).
LAW/ANALYSIS
The
  State appeals arguing the circuit court reversed Hungerfordâ€™s conviction based
  on a ground not raised in the magistrate court.[4] Â The State contends the
  arguments during the motion hearing were limited to the first video tape,
  Hungerfordâ€™s attorney did not mention Doyle during the proceedings
  before the magistrate, and Hungerfordâ€™s attorney failed to make a
  contemporaneous objection to the second video tape when it was introduced at
  trial.Â   
After
  reviewing the transcript from the magistrate court, we find the issues relied
  on by the circuit court were preserved for appellate review.Â  â€œA party need not
  use the exact name of a legal doctrine in order to preserve it, but it must be
  clear that the argument has been presented on that ground.â€Â  State v. Dunbar, 356
  S.C. 138, 142, 587 S.E.2d 691, 694 (2003).Â  In order to preserve for
  review an alleged error in admitting evidence an objection should be
  sufficiently specific to bring into focus the precise nature of the alleged
  error so it can be reasonably understood by the trial judge.Â  State v. Prioleau,
  345 S.C. 404, 411, 548 S.E.2d 213, 216 (2001).Â   
Hungerfordâ€™s
  attorney specifically stated that he had an additional objection based on a
  violation of his clientâ€™s â€œFifth
  Amendment rights, and the Miranda warnings, and in particular the
  portion of the tape after the arrest.â€ Â In
  response, the magistrate assured him that his objection was understood and he
  was â€œpreserved well on the record.â€Â Â Â  We, as an appellate court, are not in a
  position to second guess the understanding of the magistrate.Â  Additionally, there
  was no need for a contemporaneous objection because the video tapes were
  admitted immediately following the motion hearing.Â  See State v.
    Forrester, 343 S.C. 637, 642, 541 S.E.2d 837, 840 (2001) (â€œWhere a
  judge makes a ruling on the admission of evidence on the record immediately
  prior to the introduction of the evidence in question, the aggrieved party does
  not need to renew the objection.â€).
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated above, the order of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED. 
ANDERSON, SHORT, and THOMAS JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.  
[2] Miranda v. Arizona, 384 U.S. 436, 86 S.Ct. 1602 (1966).
[3] Hungerford has not argued he had a right to meet with
  or speak with counsel prior to taking the Datamaster/Breathalyzer test.Â 
 
[4] This preservation argument is the only issue argued
  by the State on appeal.Â  Accordingly, we are not reviewing the underlying
  merits of the circuit courtâ€™s reversal.

title: Irby v. Lawson
text:
THIS
  OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
  PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(D)(2), SCACR. 
 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Karen Irby, Appellant,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Augusta S.
      Lawson, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Laurens County
Â Brooks P. Goldsmith, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2008-UP-134
Submitted February 1, 2008 â€“ Filed
  February 27, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Andrew M. Jones, III, of Greenville, for Appellant.
				Edward D. Sullivan, Christian Stegmaier, both of Columbia, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Â 
  Karen Irby brought suit against Augusta Lawson for damages Irby suffered due to
  a temporary injunction that prevented her from using her property.Â  Irby
  appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order granting Lawsonâ€™s motion to dismiss pursuant
  to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP.Â  We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, and the following authorities: Glasscock, Inc. v. U.S. Fidelity and Guar. Co.,
  348 S.C. 76, 81, 557 S.E.2d 689, 691 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œSouth Carolina law
  clearly states that short, conclusory statements made without supporting
  authority are deemed abandoned on appeal and therefore not presented for review.â€);
  and Harris v. Bennett,  332 S.C. 238, 245, 503 S.E.2d 782,
  786 (Ct. App. 1998) (â€œ[A]n issue may not be raised for the first time on
  appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the court below to be
  preserved for appellate review.â€).
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., CURETON, A.J., and GOOLSBY, A. J., concur.

[1]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in
  resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument
  pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
